column3: To compare the effectiveness of two brief treatments for social anxiety disorder, you obtain a sample of individuals who have received this diagnosis, determine the severity of each subject's social anxiety, match the subjects in pairs based on the severity of their symptoms, and randomly assign one member of each pair to one of the treatments and other member to the other treatment. To compare the scores subjects in the two groups receive on a measure of symptom severity after they receive treatment, you will use which of the following?
column5: EPPP-P3-RMS-Inferential Statistical Tests-11 Answer A is correct. The first steps in identifying the appropriate statistical test are to identify the independent and dependent variables and the scale of measurement of the dependent variable. This study's independent variable is type of treatment and the dependent variable is score on a measure of severity of anxiety following treatment. More specifically, the dependent variable is score on a measure of symptom severity and, for the exam, you can assume that scores represent an interval or ratio scale. This means that a statistical test will be used to compare the mean scores obtained by two groups. The t-test and two-way ANOVA are both used to compare mean scores but, because there are only two means, the t-test is the appropriate test. To determine which t-test to use, you determine how the means were obtained: In this study, they were obtained from related groups (from groups that consist of subjects who were matched in terms of initial symptom severity). The t-test for correlated samples is the appropriate test when two means are obtained from the same group or from two groups that are related in some way.
column8: The first steps in identifying the appropriate statistical test are to identify the independent and dependent variables and the scale of measurement of the dependent variable. This study's independent variable is type of treatment and the dependent variable is score on a measure of severity of anxiety following treatment. More specifically, the dependent variable is score on a measure of symptom severity and, for the exam, you can assume that scores represent an interval or ratio scale. This means that a statistical test will be used to compare the mean scores obtained by two groups. The t-test and two-way ANOVA are both used to compare mean scores but, because there are only two means, the t-test is the appropriate test. To determine which t-test to use, you determine how the means were obtained: In this study, they were obtained from related groups (from groups that consist of subjects who were matched in terms of initial symptom severity). The t-test for correlated samples is the appropriate test when two means are obtained from the same group or from two groups that are related in some way.
column10: To compare the scores subjects in two groups receive on a measure of symptom severity after they receive treatment, a t-test for correlated samples will be used.

column3: To teach young nonspeaking children with autism spectrum disorder to communicate verbally, Lovaas (1987) used which of the following?
column5: EPPP-P3-PPA-Neurodevelopmental Disorders-01 Answer D is correct. Lovaas (1987) developed an intensive program for young children with autism that incorporated a variety of behavioral techniques. Discrimination training and shaping were two of the techniques he used to teach the children to communicate verbally.
column8: Lovaas (1987) developed an intensive program for young children with autism that incorporated a variety of behavioral techniques. Discrimination training and shaping were two of the techniques he used to teach the children to communicate verbally.
column10: Lovaas (1987) used discrimination training and shaping to teach young nonspeaking children with autism spectrum disorder to communicate verbally.

column3: When using __________ to increase a behavior, the presence of a discriminative stimulus indicates that the behavior will be reinforced.
column5: EPPP-P3-LEA-Operant Conditioning-09 Answer C is correct. As its name suggests, stimulus control involves bringing a behavior under the control of a stimulus. When the stimulus signals that a behavior will be reinforced, it's referred to as a discriminative stimulus.
column8: As its name suggests, stimulus control involves bringing a behavior under the control of a stimulus. When the stimulus signals that a behavior will be reinforced, it's referred to as a discriminative stimulus.
column10: When using stimulus control to increase a behavior, the presence of a discriminative stimulus indicates that the behavior will be reinforced.

column3: To compare the effects of three SAT review programs, a researcher randomly assigns a sample of male and female high school students who have high, average, or low test anxiety to one of the three programs. Following completion of the programs, he assesses each student's level of anxiety and performance on a mock SAT exam. This study has ___ independent variables and ___ dependent variable(s).
column5: EPPP-P3-RMS-Types of Variables and Data-01 Answer D is correct. If you're having trouble distinguishing between a study's independent and dependent variables, remember that independent variables are believed to have an effect on the dependent (outcome) variables and that, for questions like this one, anything that varies will be either an independent or dependent variable. Converting the information given in the description of the study to the following question might be helpful: "What are the effects of the [independent variable(s)] on the [dependent variable(s)]?" For this study, the question is, "What are the effects of the three review programs, initial level of test anxiety, and gender on mock SAT exam scores and level of anxiety after participation in the programs?" In other words, this study has three independent variables (program, anxiety level, and gender) and two dependent variables (SAT score and anxiety level).
column8: If you're having trouble distinguishing between a study's independent and dependent variables, remember that independent variables are believed to have an effect on the dependent (outcome) variables and that, for questions like this one, anything that varies will be either an independent or dependent variable. Converting the information given in the description of the study to the following question might be helpful: "What are the effects of the [independent variable(s)] on the [dependent variable(s)]?" For this study, the question is, "What are the effects of the three review programs, initial level of test anxiety, and gender on mock SAT exam scores and level of anxiety after participation in the programs?" In other words, this study has three independent variables (program, anxiety level, and gender) and two dependent variables (SAT score and anxiety level).
column10: This study has 3 independent variables and 2 dependent variables, comparing the effects of three SAT review programs on male and female high school students with high, average, or low test anxiety.

column3: As described by Greenson (2016), the process of analysis in psychoanalysis involves:
column4: B. confrontation, clarification, interpretation, and working through.
column5: EPPP-P3-CLI-Psychodynamic and Humanistic Therapies-01 Answer B is correct. Greenson describes the process of analysis in psychoanalysis as involving confrontation, clarification, interpretation, and working through.
column8: Greenson describes the process of analysis in psychoanalysis as involving confrontation, clarification, interpretation, and working through.
column10: Greenson describes the process of analysis in psychoanalysis as involving confrontation, clarification, interpretation, and working through.

column3: The utterance of single consonant-vowel combinations (e.g., "ba") ordinarily begins at about ____ months of age and includes __________.
column4: A. 3 to 6; sounds from various languages
column5: EPPP-P3-LIF-Language Development-08 Answer A is correct. Babbling emerges between 3 and 6 months of age and initially involves the repetition of single vowel-consonant combinations (e.g., "ba" and "ga") and includes sounds from different languages, even sounds that do not occur in the language of the baby's caregivers.
column8: Babbling emerges between 3 and 6 months of age and initially involves the repetition of single vowel-consonant combinations (e.g., "ba" and "ga") and includes sounds from different languages, even sounds that do not occur in the language of the baby's caregivers.
column10: Babbling emerges between 3 and 6 months of age and initially involves the repetition of single vowel-consonant combinations that include sounds from different languages.

column3: Wolpe attributed the effectiveness of systematic desensitization for treating anxiety to which of the following?
column5: EPPP-P3-LEA-Interventions Based on Classical Conditioning-04 Answer A is correct. Wolpe attributed the effects of systematic desensitization to reciprocal inhibition, which involves pairing presentation of a stimulus that produces anxiety with presentation of a stimulus that produces relaxation or other response that's incompatible with anxiety. As a result, the stimulus that elicits anxiety will elicit relaxation (or the other incompatible response) instead.
column8: Wolpe attributed the effects of systematic desensitization to reciprocal inhibition, which involves pairing presentation of a stimulus that produces anxiety with presentation of a stimulus that produces relaxation or other response that's incompatible with anxiety. As a result, the stimulus that elicits anxiety will elicit relaxation (or the other incompatible response) instead.
column10: Wolpe attributed the effects of systematic desensitization to reciprocal inhibition, which involves pairing presentation of a stimulus that produces anxiety with presentation of a stimulus that produces relaxation or other response that's incompatible with anxiety.

column3: A psychologist routinely administers a measure of clinical symptomology to most of his clients, who are young and middle-aged adults. Several older adults have been recently referred to him, but the measure he routinely uses has little or no information about its validity for members of this population. With regard to ethical requirements:
column4: B. it would be acceptable for the psychologist to administer this measure to older clients if alternative measures are unavailable and he explains the possible limitations of its results to the clients.
column5: EPPP-P3-ETH-APA Ethics Code Standards 9 & 10-24 Answer B is correct. This answer is most consistent with the requirements of Standard 9.02(b) of the APA Ethics Code and Standard III.8 of the Canadian Code of Ethics. Standard 9.02(b) states that, when the reliability and validity of the tests they use haven't been established for members of the population being tested, psychologists "describe the strengths and limitations of test results and interpretations." And Standard III.8 requires psychologists to acknowledge the limitations of their findings.
column8: This answer is most consistent with the requirements of Standard 9.02(b) of the APA Ethics Code and Standard III.8 of the Canadian Code of Ethics. Standard 9.02(b) states that, when the reliability and validity of the tests they use haven't been established for members of the population being tested, psychologists "describe the strengths and limitations of test results and interpretations." And Standard III.8 requires psychologists to acknowledge the limitations of their findings.
column10: The psychologist can administer the measure to older clients if alternative measures are unavailable and he explains the possible limitations of its results to the clients.

column3: Sue and Sue (2015) argue that most Western approaches to the practice of clinical psychology reflect a worldview that's characterized by:
column4: A. an internal locus of control and an internal locus of responsibility.
column5: EPPP-P3-CLI-Cross-Cultural Issues - Terms and Concepts-23 Answer A is correct. Sue and Sue describe worldview in terms of two dimensions - locus of control and locus of responsibility. They argue that most Western approaches to therapy reflect an internal locus of control and internal locus of responsibility - i.e., they're based on the assumption that people can improve their lives by taking responsibility for their own actions.
column8: Sue and Sue describe worldview in terms of two dimensions - locus of control and locus of responsibility. They argue that most Western approaches to therapy reflect an internal locus of control and internal locus of responsibility - i.e., they're based on the assumption that people can improve their lives by taking responsibility for their own actions.
column10: Sue and Sue describe most Western approaches to therapy as reflecting an internal locus of control and internal locus of responsibility.

column3: Decisional balance, self-efficacy, and temptation are core constructs of which of the following?
column5: EPPP-P3-CLI-Brief Therapies-07 Answer D is correct. The transtheoretical model identifies decisional balance, self-efficacy, and temptation as factors that affect a person's motivation to change.
column8: The transtheoretical model identifies decisional balance, self-efficacy, and temptation as factors that affect a person's motivation to change.
column10: The transtheoretical model identifies decisional balance, self-efficacy, and temptation as factors that affect a person's motivation to change.

column3: As defined in the EEOC's Uniform Guidelines on Employee Selection Procedures, ____________ may be a cause of adverse impact when members of one group consistently obtain lower scores than another group on a selection test but this score difference is not reflected in differences in job performance.
column5: EPPP-P3-ORG-Employee Selection - Evaluation of Techniques-08 Answer A is correct. The description in this question is consistent with the definition of "unfairness" given in the Uniform Guidelines on Employee Selection Procedures. It occurs when members of one group consistently obtain lower scores than another group on the predictor (e.g., selection test), but members of the two groups obtain similar scores on the criterion (e.g., measure of job performance).
column8: The description in this question is consistent with the definition of "unfairness" given in the Uniform Guidelines on Employee Selection Procedures. It occurs when members of one group consistently obtain lower scores than another group on the predictor (e.g., selection test), but members of the two groups obtain similar scores on the criterion (e.g., measure of job performance).
column10: Test unfairness occurs when members of one group consistently obtain lower scores than another group on a selection test but this score difference is not reflected in differences in job performance.

column3: A child explores the use of a block by banging it against the tray on his highchair, using it to push another block across the tray, and dropping it while sitting in his high chair. As described by Piaget, this is an example of which of the following?
column5: EPPP-P3-LIF-Cognitive Development-11 Answer D is correct. Piaget described the substages of the sensorimotor stage as including primary, secondary, and tertiary circular reactions. Tertiary circular reactions emerge between 12 and 18 months of age and involve exploring the properties of objects by, for example, using it to move another object and seeing what happens to it when it's dropped.
column8: Piaget described the substages of the sensorimotor stage as including primary, secondary, and tertiary circular reactions. Tertiary circular reactions emerge between 12 and 18 months of age and involve exploring the properties of objects by, for example, using it to move another object and seeing what happens to it when it's dropped.
column10: A child exploring the use of a block by banging it against the tray on his highchair, using it to push another block across the tray, and dropping it while sitting in his high chair is an example of tertiary circular reaction, as described by Piaget.

column3: Which of the following theories of color vision best explains the experience of negative afterimages?
column5: EPPP-P3-PHY-Sensation and Perception-13 Answer B is correct. Opponent process theory proposes that there are three types of bipolar receptor cells in the visual system - red/green, yellow/blue, and white/black. It helps explain why, after staring at the image of a red object and then looking at a white surface, we see a green afterimage of the object.
column8: Opponent process theory proposes that there are three types of bipolar receptor cells in the visual system - red/green, yellow/blue, and white/black. It helps explain why, after staring at the image of a red object and then looking at a white surface, we see a green afterimage of the object.
column10: Opponent process theory best explains the experience of negative afterimages, proposing that there are three types of bipolar receptor cells in the visual system - red/green, yellow/blue, and white/black.

column3: A psychologist designs a study to compare the effects of mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (MBCT) and mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) on the anxiety symptoms of clinic patients who have just received a diagnosis of social anxiety disorder. The study will involve randomly assigning patients to one of the two treatments and measuring their level of social anxiety during the first treatment session and one week, one month, and three months following the end of treatment. The psychologist is using which of the following research designs?
column5: EPPP-P3-RMS-Research - Single-Subject and Group Designs-06 Answer D is correct. To identify the correct answer to this question, you have to recognize that this study has two independent variables: type of treatment and time. (Time is an independent variable when the dependent variable is measured on multiple occasions during the course of the study.) Type of treatment is a between-subjects variable because each subject will participate in only one of the two interventions (MBCT or MBSR), while time is a within-subjects variable because each subject's level of anxiety will be measured four times. When a study includes at least one between-subjects variable and one within-subjects variable, the study has a mixed design.
column8: To identify the correct answer to this question, you have to recognize that this study has two independent variables: type of treatment and time. (Time is an independent variable when the dependent variable is measured on multiple occasions during the course of the study.) Type of treatment is a between-subjects variable because each subject will participate in only one of the two interventions (MBCT or MBSR), while time is a within-subjects variable because each subject's level of anxiety will be measured four times. When a study includes at least one between-subjects variable and one within-subjects variable, the study has a mixed design.
column10: A mixed research design involves randomly assigning patients to one of two treatments (mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (MBCT) or mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR)) and measuring their level of social anxiety during the first treatment session and one week, one month, and three months following the end of treatment.

column3: Compared to effectiveness research on psychotherapy outcomes, efficacy research has:
column4: B. better internal validity but worse external validity.
column5: EPPP-P3-CLI-Prevention, Consultation, and Psychotherapy Research-21 Answer B is correct. Efficacy research is conducted in highly controlled conditions and, as a result, has good internal validity; however, the results have limited external validity because they can't be generalized to less well-controlled conditions. In contrast, effectiveness research is conducted in conditions that are similar to situations in which therapy actually occurs and has limited internal validity due to limited experimental control but tends to have better external validity.
column8: Efficacy research is conducted in highly controlled conditions and, as a result, has good internal validity; however, the results have limited external validity because they can't be generalized to less well-controlled conditions. In contrast, effectiveness research is conducted in conditions that are similar to situations in which therapy actually occurs and has limited internal validity due to limited experimental control but tends to have better external validity.
column10: Efficacy research has better internal validity but worse external validity compared to effectiveness research on psychotherapy outcomes.

column3: Damage to certain areas of the __________ lobe causes perseveration, which involves repetition of the same response or action when it's inappropriate to do so in a variety of situations and on a variety of tasks.
column5: EPPP-P3-PHY-Brain Regions/Functions - Cerebral Cortex-09 Answer A is correct. Perseveration can be due to damage to other lobes of the brain but, in those cases, it's less pervasive because it's linked to the individual's other deficits. In contrast, perseveration due to frontal lobe damage is apparent in a variety of situations and on a variety of tasks.
column8: Perseveration can be due to damage to other lobes of the brain but, in those cases, it's less pervasive because it's linked to the individual's other deficits. In contrast, perseveration due to frontal lobe damage is apparent in a variety of situations and on a variety of tasks.
column10: Damage to the frontal lobe causes perseveration, which involves repetition of the same response or action when it's inappropriate to do so in a variety of situations and on a variety of tasks.

column3: Major depressive disorder has been linked to all of the following sleep abnormalities except:
column5: EPPP-P3-PPA-Bipolar and Depressive Disorders-09 Answer A is correct. Decreased REM latency (shortened latency from sleep onset to REM sleep), reduced slow-wave (stages 3 and 4) sleep, prolonged sleep latency (a longer time to fall asleep), and increased REM density (more rapid eye movements per unit of time) have been linked to major depressive disorder, especially in adults.
column8: Decreased REM latency (shortened latency from sleep onset to REM sleep), reduced slow-wave (stages 3 and 4) sleep, prolonged sleep latency (a longer time to fall asleep), and increased REM density (more rapid eye movements per unit of time) have been linked to major depressive disorder, especially in adults.
column10: Major depressive disorder has been linked to decreased REM latency, reduced slow-wave (stages 3 and 4) sleep, prolonged sleep latency, and increased REM density, but not increased REM latency.

column3: The severity of a substance use disorder is determined by which of the following?
column5: EPPP-P3-PPA-Substance-Related and Addictive Disorders-26 Answer B is correct. The severity of a substance use disorder (mild, moderate, or severe) is determined by the number of symptoms.
column8: The severity of a substance use disorder (mild, moderate, or severe) is determined by the number of symptoms.
column10: The severity of a substance use disorder (mild, moderate, or severe) is determined by the current number of symptoms.

column3: The restriction of phenotype by genotype is referred to as:
column5: EPPP-P3-LIF-Early Influences on Development - Nature vs. Nurture-01 Answer B is correct. Canalization refers to the extent to which genotype restricts phenotype to a limited number of developmental outcomes regardless of environmental circumstances. Traits and behaviors vary with regard to the degree to which they are canalized.
column7: Early Influences on Development - Nature vs. Nurture
column8: Canalization refers to the extent to which genotype restricts phenotype to a limited number of developmental outcomes regardless of environmental circumstances. Traits and behaviors vary with regard to the degree to which they are canalized.
column10: Canalization refers to the extent to which genotype restricts phenotype to a limited number of developmental outcomes regardless of environmental circumstances.

column3: You had seen Lloyd in therapy for four months when he suddenly announced he had to quit therapy because he was moving to another city to be near his parents. When Lloyd quit therapy, he owed you for his last three sessions. You have sent Lloyd two letters requesting that he pay his outstanding fees but he hasn't responded, and you are thinking about hiring a collection agency to collect the fees. With regard to ethical requirements, using a collection agency is:
column4: C. acceptable only if you notify Lloyd of your intent and give him an opportunity to pay the outstanding fees before doing so.
column5: EPPP-P3-ETH-APA Ethics Code Standards 5 & 6-14 Answer C is correct. This situation is covered in Standard 6.04(e) of the APA Ethics Code. It states that psychologists may use collection agencies and other legal measures to collect unpaid fees but "must first inform the person that such measures will be taken and provide that person an opportunity to make prompt payment." The use of a collection agency is not explicitly addressed in the Canadian Code of Ethics, but this answer is most consistent with Standard I.12, which requires psychologists to "work and act in a spirit of fair treatment to others."
column8: This situation is covered in Standard 6.04(e) of the APA Ethics Code. It states that psychologists may use collection agencies and other legal measures to collect unpaid fees but "must first inform the person that such measures will be taken and provide that person an opportunity to make prompt payment." The use of a collection agency is not explicitly addressed in the Canadian Code of Ethics, but this answer is most consistent with Standard I.12, which requires psychologists to "work and act in a spirit of fair treatment to others."
column10: Using a collection agency to collect unpaid fees is acceptable only if the psychologist notifies the client of their intent and provides the client an opportunity to make prompt payment before doing so.

column3: A newly licensed psychotherapist reacts to clients who are members of certain minority groups in ways that are consistent with stereotypes she formed about those groups during her high school and undergraduate years. Gerald Caplan (1970) described this as __________ and as a possible focus of consultee-centered case consultation.
column5: EPPP-P3-CLI-Prevention, Consultation, and Psychotherapy Research-19 Answer D is correct. Caplan described theme interference as a loss of objectivity that occurs when a therapist's reactions to a particular type of client are affected by his/her previous experiences with that type of client.
column8: Caplan described theme interference as a loss of objectivity that occurs when a therapist's reactions to a particular type of client are affected by his/her previous experiences with that type of client.
column10: Theme interference, as described by Gerald Caplan (1970), is a loss of objectivity that occurs when a therapist's reactions to a particular type of client are affected by his/her previous experiences with that type of client.

column3: Conducting a utility analysis for a new selection test would be useful for:
column4: C. obtaining information on the return on investment that can be expected when the test is used to hire job applicants.
column5: EPPP-P3-ORG-Employee Selection - Evaluation of Techniques-09 Answer C is correct. Utility analysis is used to obtain information on the monetary value (return on investment) of a selection test, training program, or other employment practice.
column8: Utility analysis is used to obtain information on the monetary value (return on investment) of a selection test, training program, or other employment practice.
column10: Conducting a utility analysis for a new selection test would be useful for obtaining information on the return on investment that can be expected when the test is used to hire job applicants.

column3: Dr. Miller has been hired by the court to conduct a court-ordered evaluation of Edward E., a defendant in a criminal case. During his first meeting with Ed, Dr. Miller informs him of the purpose of the evaluation and that it's court-ordered. Which of the following accurately describes Dr. Miller's ethical obligations with regard to informed consent in this situation?
column4: A. He does not have to obtain informed consent from Ed before proceeding with the evaluation but should inform him of the limits on confidentiality.
column5: EPPP-P3-ETH-APA Ethics Code Standards 3 & 4-08 Answer A is correct. Court-ordered evaluations are an exception to the ethical requirement to obtain an informed consent. For example, Paragraph 6.03.02 of the APA's Specialty Guidelines for Forensic Psychology states that, when an evaluation is court-ordered, forensic psychologists must describe the nature and purpose of the examination but can conduct it without obtaining the examinee's informed consent. However, in this situation, the examinee should be informed about the purpose of the evaluation, that it's court-ordered, and about limits of confidentiality. In addition, in a discussion of psychologists' responsibilities regarding moral rights, the Values Statement for Principle I of the Canadian Code of Ethics notes the following: "There might be circumstances in which the possibility of serious detrimental consequences to themselves or others, a diminished capacity to be autonomous, or a court order, would disallow aspects of some rights (e.g., privacy and confidentiality, self-determination, liberty)."
column8: Court-ordered evaluations are an exception to the ethical requirement to obtain an informed consent. For example, Paragraph 6.03.02 of the APA's Specialty Guidelines for Forensic Psychology states that, when an evaluation is court-ordered, forensic psychologists must describe the nature and purpose of the examination but can conduct it without obtaining the examinee's informed consent. However, in this situation, the examinee should be informed about the purpose of the evaluation, that it's court-ordered, and about limits of confidentiality. In addition, in a discussion of psychologists' responsibilities regarding moral rights, the Values Statement for Principle I of the Canadian Code of Ethics notes the following: "There might be circumstances in which the possibility of serious detrimental consequences to themselves or others, a diminished capacity to be autonomous, or a court order, would disallow aspects of some rights (e.g., privacy and confidentiality, self-determination, liberty)."
column10: Dr. Miller, who has been hired by the court to conduct a court-ordered evaluation of Edward E., a defendant in a criminal case, does not have to obtain informed consent from Ed before proceeding with the evaluation but should inform him of the limits on confidentiality.

column3: Studies using functional neuroimaging techniques have linked obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) to increased activity in the:
column5: EPPP-P3-PHY-Brain Regions/Functions - Hindbrain, Midbrain, and Subcortical Forebrain Structures-02 Answer B is correct. Research has found that people with OCD have increased activity in the basal ganglia (especially the caudate nucleus), the orbitofrontal cortex, and the anterior cingulate gyrus. See, e.g., S. Rauch et al., Regional cerebral blood flow during symptom provocation in obsessive-compulsive disorder using oxygen 15-labeled carbon dioxide and positron emission tomography, Archives of General Psychiatry, 51, 62-70, 1994.
column7: Brain Regions/Functions - Hindbrain, Midbrain, and Subcortical Forebrain Structures
column8: Research has found that people with OCD have increased activity in the basal ganglia (especially the caudate nucleus), the orbitofrontal cortex, and the anterior cingulate gyrus. See, e.g., S. Rauch et al., Regional cerebral blood flow during symptom provocation in obsessive-compulsive disorder using oxygen 15-labeled carbon dioxide and positron emission tomography, Archives of General Psychiatry, 51, 62-70, 1994.
column10: Research has found that people with obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) have increased activity in the basal ganglia.

column3: The subtests of the WAIS-IV have a mean of ___ and standard deviation of ___.
column5: EPPP-P3-PAS-Stanford-Binet and Wechsler Tests-05 Answer B is correct. The WAIS-IV full-scale and index scores have a mean of 100 and standard deviation of 15, and the individual subtests have a mean of 10 and standard deviation of 3.
column8: The WAIS-IV full-scale and index scores have a mean of 100 and standard deviation of 15, and the individual subtests have a mean of 10 and standard deviation of 3.
column10: The WAIS-IV full-scale and index scores have a mean of 100 and standard deviation of 15, and the individual subtests have a mean of 10 and standard deviation of 3.

column3: When using the multitrait-multimethod matrix to evaluate a test's validity, the matrix provides evidence of the test's __________ validity when scores on the test have low correlations with scores on tests that measure unrelated constructs.
column5: EPPP-P3-TES-Test Validity - Content and Construct Validity-06 Answer D is correct. The multitrait-multimethod matrix provides information on a test's convergent and divergent validity which, in turn provide information on the test's construct validity. A test has convergent validity when it has high correlations with tests that measure the same or related constructs, and it has divergent validity when it has low correlations with tests that measure unrelated constructs.
column7: Test Validity - Content and Construct Validity
column8: The multitrait-multimethod matrix provides information on a test's convergent and divergent validity which, in turn provide information on the test's construct validity. A test has convergent validity when it has high correlations with tests that measure the same or related constructs, and it has divergent validity when it has low correlations with tests that measure unrelated constructs.
column10: The multitrait-multimethod matrix provides evidence of a test's divergent validity when scores on the test have low correlations with scores on tests that measure unrelated constructs.

column3: A person who experiences recurrent and intense sexual arousal from touching or rubbing against a nonconsenting adult would receive which of the following diagnoses?
column5: EPPP-P3-PPA-Sexual Dysfunctions, Gender Dysphoria, and Paraphilic Disorders-23 Answer C is correct. Frotteuristic disorder involves recurrent and intense sexual arousal for at least six months from touching or rubbing against a nonconsenting adult as manifested in fantasies, urges, and/or behaviors.
column7: Sexual Dysfunctions, Gender Dysphoria, and Paraphilic Disorders
column8: Frotteuristic disorder involves recurrent and intense sexual arousal for at least six months from touching or rubbing against a nonconsenting adult as manifested in fantasies, urges, and/or behaviors.
column10: Frotteuristic disorder involves recurrent and intense sexual arousal for at least six months from touching or rubbing against a nonconsenting adult as manifested in fantasies, urges, and/or behaviors.

column3: The human brain is about 25% of its adult size and weight at birth, but it grows quickly and is at least 75% of its adult size and weight by _____ of age.
column5: EPPP-P3-LIF-Physical Development-07 Answer C is correct. The brain increases in size quickly following birth due primarily to an increase in nerve fibers (dendrites and axons) and glial cells, which are responsible for the myelination of nerve fibers. It reaches at least 75% its adult size and weight by about 24 months of age.
column8: The brain increases in size quickly following birth due primarily to an increase in nerve fibers (dendrites and axons) and glial cells, which are responsible for the myelination of nerve fibers. It reaches at least 75% its adult size and weight by about 24 months of age.
column10: The human brain increases in size quickly following birth due primarily to an increase in nerve fibers and glial cells and reaches at least 75% its adult size and weight by about 24 months of age.

column3: Practitioners of Ellis's rational emotive behavior therapy (REBT) view emotions and behaviors as the result of a chain of events that's depicted as A-B-C. In this chain, B refers to a person's:
column5: EPPP-P3-CLI-Cognitive-Behavioral Therapies-17 Answer C is correct. In Ellis's A-B-C model, A is the antecedent event, B is the person's beliefs about that event, and C is the person's emotional or behavioral response to those beliefs.
column8: In Ellis's A-B-C model, A is the antecedent event, B is the person's beliefs about that event, and C is the person's emotional or behavioral response to those beliefs.
column10: In Ellis's A-B-C model, A is the antecedent event, B is the person's beliefs about that event, and C is the person's emotional or behavioral response to those beliefs.

column3: A heritability estimate for a particular trait is most useful for understanding the extent to which:
column4: B. variability in the trait in a given population is due to genetic versus environmental factors.
column5: EPPP-P3-LIF-Early Influences on Development - Nature vs. Nurture-02 Answer B is correct. A heritability estimate indicates the extent to which variability in phenotype in a given population is attributable to differences in genotype. Because it applies to a population, it cannot be used to determine the extent to which an individual's status with regard to a particular trait is due to genetic versus environmental influences.
column7: Early Influences on Development - Nature vs. Nurture
column8: A heritability estimate indicates the extent to which variability in phenotype in a given population is attributable to differences in genotype. Because it applies to a population, it cannot be used to determine the extent to which an individual's status with regard to a particular trait is due to genetic versus environmental influences.
column10: A heritability estimate indicates the extent to which variability in phenotype in a given population is attributable to differences in genotype.

column3: The prototype/willingness model (Gibbons & Gerard, 1995) defines a "prototype" as:
column4: B. a person's image of the "typical" person who engages in a specific behavior.
column5: EPPP-P3-SOC-Attitudes and Attitude Change-04 Answer B is correct. According to the prototype/willingness model, a person's willingness to engage in a behavior depends on the person's perceived acceptability of the behavior that, in turn, is determined by the person's prototype (social image) of people who engage in that behavior.
column8: According to the prototype/willingness model, a person's willingness to engage in a behavior depends on the person's perceived acceptability of the behavior that, in turn, is determined by the person's prototype (social image) of people who engage in that behavior.
column10: According to the prototype/willingness model, a person's willingness to engage in a behavior depends on the person's perceived acceptability of the behavior that, in turn, is determined by the person's prototype (social image) of people who engage in that behavior.

column3: Which of the following is used to estimate the effect of increasing a predictor's reliability on its criterion-related validity coefficient?
column5: EPPP-P3-TES-Test Validity - Criterion-Related Validity-10 Answer B is correct. Inadequate reliability is one of the factors that reduces a predictor's criterion-related validity coefficient, and the correction for attenuation formula is used to estimate the effect of increasing the reliability of the predictor and/or criterion on the predictor's criterion-related validity coefficient.
column8: Inadequate reliability is one of the factors that reduces a predictor's criterion-related validity coefficient, and the correction for attenuation formula is used to estimate the effect of increasing the reliability of the predictor and/or criterion on the predictor's criterion-related validity coefficient.
column10: The correction for attenuation formula is used to estimate the effect of increasing a predictor's reliability on its criterion-related validity coefficient.

column3: According to Holland's (1985) theory of career choice, the realistic personality type is most similar to which of the following types?
column5: EPPP-P3-ORG-Career Choice and Development-12 Answer A is correct. Holland depicted his six personality and work environment types ("RIASEC") arranged around a hexagon, with the types closest to each other in the hexagon being most similar and those farthest from each other being most dissimilar. Realistic is most similar to investigative and conventional and most dissimilar to social.
column8: Holland depicted his six personality and work environment types ("RIASEC") arranged around a hexagon, with the types closest to each other in the hexagon being most similar and those farthest from each other being most dissimilar. Realistic is most similar to investigative and conventional and most dissimilar to social.
column10: Holland's theory depicts the realistic personality type as most similar to the investigative and conventional types and most dissimilar to the social type.

column3: Which of the following best describes current thinking about the use of no-suicide contracts?
column4: D. They are not an effective tool for preventing suicide.
column5: EPPP-P3-PPA-Bipolar and Depressive Disorders-10 Answer D is correct. There's growing consensus that no-suicide contracts should not be used or should be used with caution because there's no empirical evidence that they reduce the risk for suicide or provide legal protection for therapists. In addition, they may have negative effects by giving therapists a false sense of security about a client's risk for suicide. See, e.g., L. A. Hoff, Crisis: How to help yourself and others in distress and danger, New York, Oxford University Press, 2015.
column8: There's growing consensus that no-suicide contracts should not be used or should be used with caution because there's no empirical evidence that they reduce the risk for suicide or provide legal protection for therapists. In addition, they may have negative effects by giving therapists a false sense of security about a client's risk for suicide. See, e.g., L. A. Hoff, Crisis: How to help yourself and others in distress and danger, New York, Oxford University Press, 2015.
column10: There is growing consensus that no-suicide contracts are not an effective tool for preventing suicide and should not be used or should be used with caution.

column3: Frame-of-reference training is a type of training that focuses on:
column4: A. helping raters recognize the multidimensionality of job performance and what constitutes different levels of performance.
column5: EPPP-P3-ORG-Job Analysis and Performance Assessment-04 Answer A is correct. Frame-of-reference (FOR) training is a type of rater training that involves (a) ensuring that trainees understand the multidimensional nature of job performance and the organization's definition of successful and unsuccessful performance and (b) giving trainees opportunities to practice assigning ratings and receive feedback about their rating accuracy. Frame-of-reference training has been found to be more effective than training that focuses on rater biases.
column8: Frame-of-reference (FOR) training is a type of rater training that involves (a) ensuring that trainees understand the multidimensional nature of job performance and the organization's definition of successful and unsuccessful performance and (b) giving trainees opportunities to practice assigning ratings and receive feedback about their rating accuracy. Frame-of-reference training has been found to be more effective than training that focuses on rater biases.
column10: Frame-of-reference training focuses on helping raters recognize the multidimensionality of job performance and what constitutes different levels of performance.

column3: With regard to leadership style, which of the following is the best conclusion that can be drawn about the effects of consideration and initiating structure on job outcomes?
column4: C. A high level of consideration is more important for satisfaction, while a high level of initiating structure is more important for performance.
column5: EPPP-P3-ORG-Organizational Leadership-17 Answer C is correct. Judge, Piccolo, and Ilies's (2004) meta-analysis of the research on leadership style found that a high level of consideration was more strongly related to subordinate satisfaction and motivation, while a high level of initiating structure was more strongly related to leader and group performance
column8: Judge, Piccolo, and Ilies's (2004) meta-analysis of the research on leadership style found that a high level of consideration was more strongly related to subordinate satisfaction and motivation, while a high level of initiating structure was more strongly related to leader and group performance
column10: A high level of consideration is more important for subordinate satisfaction, while a high level of initiating structure is more important for performance.

column3: Regardless of the distribution of raw scores, when the raw scores are converted to percentile ranks, the resulting distribution will be:
column5: EPPP-P3-TES-Test Score Interpretation-11 Answer B is correct. A percentile rank distribution is always rectangular (flat) because the same percent of scores fall at each percentile rank. In other words, when raw test scores are converted to percentile ranks, 1% of the scores will be converted to each percentile rank: The highest 1% of raw scores will be converted to a percentile rank of 100, the next highest 1% of raw scores will be converted to a percentile rank of 99, etc.
column8: A percentile rank distribution is always rectangular (flat) because the same percent of scores fall at each percentile rank. In other words, when raw test scores are converted to percentile ranks, 1% of the scores will be converted to each percentile rank: The highest 1% of raw scores will be converted to a percentile rank of 100, the next highest 1% of raw scores will be converted to a percentile rank of 99, etc.
column10: When raw scores are converted to percentile ranks, the resulting distribution will be rectangular.

column3: Damon (1988) proposed that children's friendships develop in three stages, the last of which is:
column5: EPPP-P3-LIF-Socioemotional Development - Attachment, Emotions, and Social Relationships-22 Answer B is correct. Damon's three stages of friendship are handy playmate (ages 4 to 7 years), mutual trust and assistance (8 to 10 years), and intimacy and loyalty (11+ years). Intimate and mutually shared relationships and mature friendships are the last two friendship stages identified by Selman (1981).
column7: Socioemotional Development - Attachment, Emotions, and Social Relationships
column8: Damon's three stages of friendship are handy playmate (ages 4 to 7 years), mutual trust and assistance (8 to 10 years), and intimacy and loyalty (11+ years). Intimate and mutually shared relationships and mature friendships are the last two friendship stages identified by Selman (1981).
column10: Damon's three stages of friendship development are handy playmate, mutual trust and assistance, and intimacy and loyalty.

column3: With regard to gender and leader effectiveness, the research has found that:
column4: A. female leaders are rated as more effective in feminine work settings, while male leaders are rated as more effective in masculine work settings.
column5: EPPP-P3-ORG-Organizational Leadership-18 Answer A is correct. The studies suggest that, overall, men and women do not differ in perceived leader effectiveness. There's evidence, however, that female leaders tend to be rated as more effective in traditionally feminine situations while male leaders tend to be rated as more effective in traditionally masculine situations (Eagly, Karau, & Makhijani, 1995).
column8: The studies suggest that, overall, men and women do not differ in perceived leader effectiveness. There's evidence, however, that female leaders tend to be rated as more effective in traditionally feminine situations while male leaders tend to be rated as more effective in traditionally masculine situations (Eagly, Karau, & Makhijani, 1995).
column10: Female leaders are rated as more effective in feminine work settings, while male leaders are rated as more effective in masculine work settings.

column3: Which of the following is not required for a DSM-5 diagnosis of anorexia nervosa?
column4: B. dieting or fasting to maintain low body weight
column5: EPPP-P3-PPA-Feeding/Eating, Elimination, and Sleep-Wake Disorders-19 Answer B is correct. The diagnosis of anorexia nervosa requires a restriction in energy intake that leads to a significantly low body weight, but the restriction can involve dieting or fasting or binge-eating and purging. In other words, the diagnosis can be assigned even when the person is not engaging in dieting or fasting.
column8: The diagnosis of anorexia nervosa requires a restriction in energy intake that leads to a significantly low body weight, but the restriction can involve dieting or fasting or binge-eating and purging. In other words, the diagnosis can be assigned even when the person is not engaging in dieting or fasting.
column10: The diagnosis of anorexia nervosa does not require dieting or fasting to maintain low body weight.

column3: Which of the following is NOT an example of a technostructural intervention?
column5: EPPP-P3-ORG-Organizational Change and Development-16 Answer B is correct. Technostructural interventions focus on an organization's technology or structure and include business process reengineering, downsizing, job enrichment, and alternative work schedules.
column8: Technostructural interventions focus on an organization's technology or structure and include business process reengineering, downsizing, job enrichment, and alternative work schedules.
column10: Process consultation is not an example of a technostructural intervention.

column3: Episodic and semantic memory are types of:
column5: EPPP-P3-LEA-Memory and Forgetting-12 Answer C is correct. Long-term memory is divided into procedural and declarative memory, with declarative memory being further divided into episodic and semantic memory.
column8: Long-term memory is divided into procedural and declarative memory, with declarative memory being further divided into episodic and semantic memory.
column10: Episodic and semantic memory are types of declarative memory.

column3: Research has linked a chronically elevated level of the hormone __________ to a loss of neurons in the hippocampus and memory impairment.
column5: EPPP-P3-ORG-Satisfaction, Commitment, and Stress-24 Answer B is correct. A chronically elevated level of the stress hormone cortisol has been linked to a number of undesirable consequences. One consequence is impaired memory, which is due to its effects on the hippocampus.
column8: A chronically elevated level of the stress hormone cortisol has been linked to a number of undesirable consequences. One consequence is impaired memory, which is due to its effects on the hippocampus.
column10: A chronically elevated level of the stress hormone cortisol has been linked to a loss of neurons in the hippocampus and memory impairment.

column3: When designing a research study, you would use the double-blind technique to reduce which of the following?
column5: EPPP-P3-RMS-Research - Internal/External Validity-04 Answer A is correct. When using the single-blind technique, subjects do not know which groups they are in (e.g., drug or placebo); when using the double-blind technique, subjects and experimenters do not know what groups subjects are in. An advantage of the double-blind technique is that it reduces experimenter expectancy, which is also known as experimenter bias and refers to the effects of the experimenter's knowledge about the purpose of the study on the study's outcomes. Neither the single-blind nor the double-blind technique are useful for controlling carryover effects or pretest sensitization which are threats to a study's external and internal validity, respectively. The false consensus effect is not relevant to internal or external validity and is the tendency to overestimate the extent to which other people share our opinions, values, and beliefs
column8: When using the single-blind technique, subjects do not know which groups they are in (e.g., drug or placebo); when using the double-blind technique, subjects and experimenters do not know what groups subjects are in. An advantage of the double-blind technique is that it reduces experimenter expectancy, which is also known as experimenter bias and refers to the effects of the experimenter's knowledge about the purpose of the study on the study's outcomes. Neither the single-blind nor the double-blind technique are useful for controlling carryover effects or pretest sensitization which are threats to a study's external and internal validity, respectively. The false consensus effect is not relevant to internal or external validity and is the tendency to overestimate the extent to which other people share our opinions, values, and beliefs
column10: The double-blind technique reduces experimenter expectancy when designing a research study.

column3: A program that targets the academic and behavioral functioning of children in elementary school whose parents have a substance use disorder is an example of which type of prevention?
column5: EPPP-P3-CLI-Prevention, Consultation, and Psychotherapy Research-10 Answer B is correct. Gordon's (1983) model of prevention distinguishes between the three types of prevention listed in answers A, B, and D. Universal preventions are available to all members of a population (e.g., all elementary school children). Selective preventions are aimed at members of a subgroup of a population who are at above-average risk for a condition or problem (e.g., all elementary school children whose parents have a substance use disorder). Indicated preventions are aimed at specific individuals from a population who are not only at-risk for a condition or problem but also have minimal but detectable signs or symptoms of the condition or problem (e.g., all elementary children whose parents have a substance use disorder and have early signs of academic and behavioral problems).
column8: Gordon's (1983) model of prevention distinguishes between the three types of prevention listed in answers A, B, and D. Universal preventions are available to all members of a population (e.g., all elementary school children). Selective preventions are aimed at members of a subgroup of a population who are at above-average risk for a condition or problem (e.g., all elementary school children whose parents have a substance use disorder). Indicated preventions are aimed at specific individuals from a population who are not only at-risk for a condition or problem but also have minimal but detectable signs or symptoms of the condition or problem (e.g., all elementary children whose parents have a substance use disorder and have early signs of academic and behavioral problems).
column10: A program that targets the academic and behavioral functioning of children in elementary school whose parents have a substance use disorder is an example of selected prevention.

column3: All of the following drugs slow the cognitive decline caused by Alzheimer's disease by increasing cholinergic activity except:
column5: EPPP-P3-PHY-Psychopharmacology - Other Psychoactive Drugs-24 Answer B is correct. All four drugs listed in the answers to this question are used to slow the progress of cognitive decline caused by Alzheimer's disease. Galantamine (Razadyne), rivastigmine (Exelon), and donepezil (Aricept) do so by increasing cholinergic activity (i.e., by preventing the breakdown of the neurotransmitter acetylcholine), while memantine (Namenda) reduces the negative effects of excessive levels of the neurotransmitter glutamate.
column8: All four drugs listed in the answers to this question are used to slow the progress of cognitive decline caused by Alzheimer's disease. Galantamine (Razadyne), rivastigmine (Exelon), and donepezil (Aricept) do so by increasing cholinergic activity (i.e., by preventing the breakdown of the neurotransmitter acetylcholine), while memantine (Namenda) reduces the negative effects of excessive levels of the neurotransmitter glutamate.
column10: Memantine, unlike galantamine, rivastigmine, and donepezil, does not slow the cognitive decline caused by Alzheimer's disease by increasing cholinergic activity.

column3: A parent who is using positive reinforcement to establish a desirable behavior in her child will switch from a continuous schedule of reinforcement to an intermittent schedule in order to reduce the risk for:
column5: EPPP-P3-LEA-Operant Conditioning-08 Answer B is correct. Satiation occurs when a reinforcer is no longer reinforcing because the person is satiated (no longer desires the reinforcer). Switching from a continuous schedule to an intermittent schedule once the behavior is occurring at the desired level helps reduce the risk for satiation.
column8: Satiation occurs when a reinforcer is no longer reinforcing because the person is satiated (no longer desires the reinforcer). Switching from a continuous schedule to an intermittent schedule once the behavior is occurring at the desired level helps reduce the risk for satiation.
column10: Switching from a continuous schedule to an intermittent schedule of reinforcement reduces the risk for satiation when a parent is using positive reinforcement to establish a desirable behavior in their child.

column3: Mark Martinez is a graduate student in clinical psychology and is on-staff at a behavioral health clinic. He notices that the clinic's most recent newspaper ad lists staff members and their credentials and identifies him as "Ph.D. (Cand.)." This designation of Mark's credentials is:
column4: D. unacceptable even if it accurately identifies his status.
column5: EPPP-P3-ETH-APA Ethics Code Standards 5 & 6-12 Answer D is correct. The use of "Ph.D. (Cand.)" or similar designation violates Standard 5.01 of the APA Ethics Code and Standard III.2 of the Canadian Code of Ethics, which require psychologists to avoid false, deceptive, or fraudulent public statements. As noted by Koocher and Keith-Spiegel (2008), "Ph.D. (Cand.)" and "Ph.D. Candidate" are misleading because they imply that the person has some type of earned credential.
column8: The use of "Ph.D. (Cand.)" or similar designation violates Standard 5.01 of the APA Ethics Code and Standard III.2 of the Canadian Code of Ethics, which require psychologists to avoid false, deceptive, or fraudulent public statements. As noted by Koocher and Keith-Spiegel (2008), "Ph.D. (Cand.)" and "Ph.D. Candidate" are misleading because they imply that the person has some type of earned credential.
column10: The designation "Ph.D. (Cand.)" is unacceptable even if it accurately identifies a graduate student's status, as it violates ethical standards by implying an earned credential.

column3: Your new client is Edna, age 22, who's brought to therapy by her mother. Edna says that, for about two months, she's often felt like she doesn't have any emotions or thoughts and is going through life "like a robot." Her mother reports that, as a teenager, Edna sometimes said "she felt weird, like she wasn't herself" but that "this time, it's a lot worse." Edna says she often feels lightheaded and loses her balance. She also states that she quit her job three weeks ago because the way she feels made her anxious at work and unable to do her job. Since then, she's stayed in the house and has been "trying to figure out what's going on." Assuming that Edna's symptoms are not due to substance use or a medical condition, the most likely diagnosis is:
column5: EPPP-P3-PPA-Trauma/Stressor-Related, Dissociative, and Somatic Symptom Disorders-17 Answer D is correct. Edna's symptoms are characteristic of depersonalization which is defined in the DSM-5 as involving a "sense of unreality, detachment, or being an outside observer with respect to one's thoughts, feelings, sensations, body, or actions" (p. 302). People with depersonalization/derealization disorder may say they feel like a robot or automaton, have vague somatic symptoms (e.g., lightheadedness), and experience anxiety or depression.
column7: Trauma/Stressor-Related, Dissociative, and Somatic Symptom Disorders
column8: Edna's symptoms are characteristic of depersonalization which is defined in the DSM-5 as involving a "sense of unreality, detachment, or being an outside observer with respect to one's thoughts, feelings, sensations, body, or actions" (p. 302). People with depersonalization/derealization disorder may say they feel like a robot or automaton, have vague somatic symptoms (e.g., lightheadedness), and experience anxiety or depression.
column10: The most likely diagnosis for Edna's symptoms of feeling like a "robot" and experiencing depersonalization, derealization, and somatic symptoms, without substance use or a medical condition, is depersonalization/derealization disorder.

column3: The DSM-5 diagnosis of attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) requires the onset of some symptoms before _____ years of age.
column5: EPPP-P3-PPA-Neurodevelopmental Disorders-02 Answer C is correct. For the diagnosis of ADHD, the individual must have had some symptoms of inattention and/or hyperactivity-impulsivity prior to 12 years of age.
column8: For the diagnosis of ADHD, the individual must have had some symptoms of inattention and/or hyperactivity-impulsivity prior to 12 years of age.
column10: The DSM-5 diagnosis of attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) requires the onset of some symptoms before 12 years of age.

column3: According to Vygotsky, children's ______ play provides them with a zone of proximal development.
column5: EPPP-P3-LIF-Cognitive Development-13 Answer B is correct. Vygotsky believed that make-believe play is a sociocultural activity that provides children with a zone of proximal development in which they can adopt roles and engage in behaviors associated with those roles that they can't do in everyday life.
column8: Vygotsky believed that make-believe play is a sociocultural activity that provides children with a zone of proximal development in which they can adopt roles and engage in behaviors associated with those roles that they can't do in everyday life.
column10: According to Vygotsky, children's make-believe play provides them with a zone of proximal development.

column3: Confabulation on the Rorschach occurs when a patient overgeneralizes from a part of an inkblot to the whole inkblot and is associated with which of the following?
column5: EPPP-P3-PAS-Other Measures of Personality-02 Answer C is correct. Confabulation involves overgeneralizing from one detail of an inkblot to the whole inkblot and is associated with a thought disorder caused by organic brain injury or a functional disorder. (Note that Rorschach's use of this term differs from its use elsewhere to describe the tendency of individuals with some types of amnesia to make-up information to fill-in memory gaps.)
column8: Confabulation involves overgeneralizing from one detail of an inkblot to the whole inkblot and is associated with a thought disorder caused by organic brain injury or a functional disorder. (Note that Rorschach's use of this term differs from its use elsewhere to describe the tendency of individuals with some types of amnesia to make-up information to fill-in memory gaps.)
column10: Confabulation on the Rorschach, which involves overgeneralizing from one detail of an inkblot to the whole inkblot, is associated with a thought disorder caused by organic brain injury or a functional disorder.

column3: The personnel committee at a school of professional psychology has decided to deny Dr. Valdez a promotion because one of his clinic clients recently filed an ethics complaint against him. The client's complaint claims that Dr. Valdez breached the client's confidentiality by revealing information she told him in individual therapy during a group therapy session without her permission to do so. With regard to ethical requirements, the committee's decision is:
column4: C. unacceptable if the decision to deny Dr. Valdez's promotion was based solely on the pending ethics complaint.
column5: EPPP-P3-ETH-APA Ethics Code Overview and Standards 1 & 2-02 Answer C is correct. This answer is consistent with Standard 1.08 of the APA Ethics Code and Standard I.13 of the Canadian Code of Ethics. Standard 1.08 directly addresses this situation and states that psychologists must not "deny persons employment, advancement, admissions to academic or other programs, tenure, or promotion, based solely upon their having made or their being the subject of an ethics complaint." And Standard I.13 indirectly addresses this situation and requires psychologists to "abide by due process and other natural justice procedures for employment, evaluation, adjudication, editorial, and peer review activities."
column7: APA Ethics Code Overview and Standards 1 & 2
column8: This answer is consistent with Standard 1.08 of the APA Ethics Code and Standard I.13 of the Canadian Code of Ethics. Standard 1.08 directly addresses this situation and states that psychologists must not "deny persons employment, advancement, admissions to academic or other programs, tenure, or promotion, based solely upon their having made or their being the subject of an ethics complaint." And Standard I.13 indirectly addresses this situation and requires psychologists to "abide by due process and other natural justice procedures for employment, evaluation, adjudication, editorial, and peer review activities."
column10: Denying a psychologist a promotion based solely on a pending ethics complaint against them would be unacceptable, as it violates ethical standards that require due process and natural justice procedures for employment decisions.

column3: When using classical conditioning to establish a conditioned response, the most effective method is:
column5: EPPP-P3-LEA-Classical Conditioning-02 Answer C is correct. Trace conditioning, simultaneous conditioning, and delay conditioning are more effective than backwards conditioning and, of the three, delay conditioning is best. It involves presenting the conditioned stimulus so that it precedes and overlaps presentation of the unconditioned stimulus.
column8: Trace conditioning, simultaneous conditioning, and delay conditioning are more effective than backwards conditioning and, of the three, delay conditioning is best. It involves presenting the conditioned stimulus so that it precedes and overlaps presentation of the unconditioned stimulus.
column10: Delay conditioning, where the conditioned stimulus precedes and overlaps presentation of the unconditioned stimulus, is the most effective method for establishing a conditioned response through classical conditioning.

column3: A test's __________ is the proportion of people who have a disorder and are correctly identified by the test as having the disorder.
column5: EPPP-P3-TES-Test Validity - Criterion-Related Validity-09 Answer A is correct. Determining a test's sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value, and negative predictive value are one way of evaluating its validity. A test's sensitivity refers to the test's ability to accurately identify people who have the disease or other attribute the test was designed to identify. It's calculated by dividing the number of true positives by the number of true positives plus false negatives.
column8: Determining a test's sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value, and negative predictive value are one way of evaluating its validity. A test's sensitivity refers to the test's ability to accurately identify people who have the disease or other attribute the test was designed to identify. It's calculated by dividing the number of true positives by the number of true positives plus false negatives.
column10: The sensitivity of a test is the proportion of people who have a disorder and are correctly identified by the test as having the disorder.

column3: To confirm a diagnosis of intellectual disability for a nine-year-old child, you would administer the SB5 or other measure of intelligence along with which of the following?
column5: EPPP-P3-PAS-Clinical Tests-11 Answer B is correct. The DSM-5 diagnosis of intellectual disability requires the presence of deficits in both intellectual and adaptive functioning. The Vineland-3 is a measure of adaptive functioning.
column8: The DSM-5 diagnosis of intellectual disability requires the presence of deficits in both intellectual and adaptive functioning. The Vineland-3 is a measure of adaptive functioning.
column10: To confirm a diagnosis of intellectual disability for a 9-year-old child, one would administer a measure of intelligence along with the Vineland-3, a measure of adaptive functioning.

column3: Dr. King teaches classes on neuropsychology and conducts research on neurological correlates of aging at a large university. In her introductory neuropsychology class, she covers only research on aging that's produced results that are similar to her own studies. In terms of the requirements of the ethics codes of the American and Canadian Psychological Associations, this is:
column5: EPPP-P3-ETH-APA Ethics Code Standards 7 & 8-19 Answer D is correct. This issue is addressed in Standard 7.03 of the APA Ethics Code and Standard III.11 of the Canadian Code of Ethics, which both require psychologists to present instructional information in an accurate and unbiased manner.
column8: This issue is addressed in Standard 7.03 of the APA Ethics Code and Standard III.11 of the Canadian Code of Ethics, which both require psychologists to present instructional information in an accurate and unbiased manner.
column10: Covering only research on aging that produces results similar to one's own studies in an introductory neuropsychology class would be unacceptable, as it violates ethical requirements to present instructional information in an accurate and unbiased manner.

column3: Which of the following is not one of the three major dimensions of temperament identified by Rothbart (2011)?
column5: EPPP-P3-LIF-Socioemotional Development - Temperament and Personality-17 Answer B is correct. The three dimensions of temperament identified by Rothbart are surgency/extraversion, negative affectivity, and effortful control. See, e.g., M. Rothbart, Becoming who we are: Temperament and personality in development, New York, Guilford Press, 2011.
column8: The three dimensions of temperament identified by Rothbart are surgency/extraversion, negative affectivity, and effortful control. See, e.g., M. Rothbart, Becoming who we are: Temperament and personality in development, New York, Guilford Press, 2011.
column10: The three major dimensions of temperament identified by Rothbart are not approach/withdrawal, but rather surgency/extraversion, negative affectivity, and effortful control.

column3: A score ___ on the Mini-Mental State Exam (MMSE) indicates normal functioning:
column5: EPPP-P3-PAS-Clinical Tests-10 Answer C is correct. The MMSE is a screening test for cognitive impairment, and scores range from 0 to 30. A score of 24 or higher is interpreted as normal functioning. Lower scores indicate cognitive impairment and, the lower the score, the greater the impairment.
column8: The MMSE is a screening test for cognitive impairment, and scores range from 0 to 30. A score of 24 or higher is interpreted as normal functioning. Lower scores indicate cognitive impairment and, the lower the score, the greater the impairment.
column10: A score above 24 on the Mini-Mental State Exam (MMSE) indicates normal cognitive functioning.

column3: For a test that consists of 50 true/false questions, the optimal average item difficulty level (p) is:
column5: EPPP-P3-TES-Item Analysis and Test Reliability-01 Answer B is correct. The optimal difficulty level for test questions depends on several factors including the chance that examinees can choose the correct answers just by guessing. With regard to this factor, the optimal difficulty level falls halfway between 100% and the probability of choosing the correct answer by guessing: For true/false questions, the probability of guessing correctly is 50%, so the optimal difficulty level is halfway between 1.0 and .50, which is .75.
column8: The optimal difficulty level for test questions depends on several factors including the chance that examinees can choose the correct answers just by guessing. With regard to this factor, the optimal difficulty level falls halfway between 100% and the probability of choosing the correct answer by guessing: For true/false questions, the probability of guessing correctly is 50%, so the optimal difficulty level is halfway between 1.0 and .50, which is .75.
column10: The optimal average item difficulty level (p) for a test with 50 true/false questions is 0.75.

column3: When Milgram (1974) asked psychiatrists to predict how many "teachers" would obey the experimenter's order to deliver the highest levels of shock to the "learner," the psychiatrists predicted that __________ would do so.
column5: EPPP-P3-SOC-Social Influence - Types of Influence-08 Answer D is correct. Before conducting his initial studies, Milgram asked a group of psychiatrists to predict how many subjects would be willing to deliver the highest levels of shock, and they predicted that only a "pathological fringe" of 1 in 1,000 would do so.
column8: Before conducting his initial studies, Milgram asked a group of psychiatrists to predict how many subjects would be willing to deliver the highest levels of shock, and they predicted that only a "pathological fringe" of 1 in 1,000 would do so.
column10: Before conducting his studies, Milgram asked psychiatrists to predict that only 1 in 1,000 "teachers" would obey the experimenter's order to deliver the highest levels of shock to the "learner".

column3: Research has found that electrical stimulation of different areas of the ___________ in cats and other animal species produces different types of aggressive behavior.
column5: EPPP-P3-PHY-Brain Regions/Functions - Hindbrain, Midbrain, and Subcortical Forebrain Structures-04 Answer A is correct. Various areas of the hypothalamus have been linked to different types of aggressive behavior in several animal species. For example, research with cats has found that electrical stimulation of the medial hypothalamus usually produces affective attack behavior, while electrical stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus produces stalking attack behavior. See, e.g., M. Wasman and J. P. Flynn, Directed attack elicited from the hypothalamus, Archives of Neurology, 6, 208-219, 1962.
column7: Brain Regions/Functions - Hindbrain, Midbrain, and Subcortical Forebrain Structures
column8: Various areas of the hypothalamus have been linked to different types of aggressive behavior in several animal species. For example, research with cats has found that electrical stimulation of the medial hypothalamus usually produces affective attack behavior, while electrical stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus produces stalking attack behavior. See, e.g., M. Wasman and J. P. Flynn, Directed attack elicited from the hypothalamus, Archives of Neurology, 6, 208-219, 1962.
column10: Various areas of the hypothalamus have been linked to different types of aggressive behavior in several animal species, with electrical stimulation of the medial hypothalamus usually producing affective attack behavior and electrical stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus producing stalking attack behavior in cats and other animal species.

column3: A psychology professor at a large university has just developed a new screening test for depression and wants to compare scores on her test to scores on the Beck Depression Inventory and two other measures of depressive symptoms. She will do so by having a sample of adults who have and have not received a diagnosis of major depressive disorder complete the four measures. If the professor hires psychology graduate students to administer the measures to participants, this will be:
column4: D. acceptable as long as the students are provided with training in administering the measures and relevant ethical guidelines.
column5: EPPP-P3-ETH-APA Ethics Code Overview and Standards 1 & 2-03 Answer D is correct. This answer is most consistent with Standard 2.05 of the APA Ethics Code and Standard II.7 of the Canadian Code of Ethics, which require psychologists to delegate to others only work they're competent to perform. In the situation described in this question, this would include ensuring that the students administering the tests have adequate training in test administration and relevant ethical requirements.
column7: APA Ethics Code Overview and Standards 1 & 2
column8: This answer is most consistent with Standard 2.05 of the APA Ethics Code and Standard II.7 of the Canadian Code of Ethics, which require psychologists to delegate to others only work they're competent to perform. In the situation described in this question, this would include ensuring that the students administering the tests have adequate training in test administration and relevant ethical requirements.
column10: Hiring psychology graduate students to administer measures is acceptable as long as the students are provided with training in administering the measures and relevant ethical guidelines.

column3: The WAIS-IV General Ability Index (GAI) score can be used to obtain a measure of an examinee's intelligence that minimizes the effects of:
column4: A. working memory and processing speed.
column5: EPPP-P3-PAS-Stanford-Binet and Wechsler Tests-06 Answer A is correct. The GAI score is determined by scores on the core Verbal Comprehension Index and Perceptual Reasoning Index subtests and is useful when it's desirable to obtain a measure of intelligence that minimizes the effects of working memory and processing speed.
column8: The GAI score is determined by scores on the core Verbal Comprehension Index and Perceptual Reasoning Index subtests and is useful when it's desirable to obtain a measure of intelligence that minimizes the effects of working memory and processing speed.
column10: The WAIS-IV General Ability Index (GAI) score is useful for obtaining a measure of intelligence that minimizes the effects of working memory and processing speed.

column3: An African American therapy client who prefers to see a White therapist and doesn't think prejudice and discrimination have contributed to his current problems is in which stage of Cross's (2001) model of Black racial identity development?
column5: EPPP-P3-CLI-Cross-Cultural Issues - Terms and Concepts-27 Answer D is correct.
