Cross's (2001) model of Black racial identity development distinguishes between four stages: pre-encounter, encounter, immersion/emersion, and internalization. Racial identity has low salience for clients in the pre-encounter stage, and these clients ordinarily prefer a White therapist.
column8: Cross's (2001) model of Black racial identity development distinguishes between four stages: pre-encounter, encounter, immersion/emersion, and internalization. Racial identity has low salience for clients in the pre-encounter stage, and these clients ordinarily prefer a White therapist.
column10: Clients in the pre-encounter stage of Cross's (2001) model of Black racial identity development have low racial identity salience and ordinarily prefer a White therapist.

column3: A child says he doesn't steal because it's against the law. Based on this information, you can conclude that this child is in which of Kohlberg's levels of moral development?
column5: EPPP-P3-LIF-Socioemotional Development - Moral Development-23 Answer B is correct. The second stage of Kohlberg's conventional level is the law and order orientation stage. During this stage, judgments about the acceptability of a behavior depend on whether or not the behavior violates laws and rules that have been established by legitimate authorities.
column8: The second stage of Kohlberg's conventional level is the law and order orientation stage. During this stage, judgments about the acceptability of a behavior depend on whether or not the behavior violates laws and rules that have been established by legitimate authorities.
column10: The child who doesn't steal because it's against the law is in the law and order orientation stage of Kohlberg's conventional level of moral development.

column3: A practitioner of Bowenian extended family systems therapy will use a genogram to obtain information about:
column4: A. the relationships among family members over multiple generations.
column5: EPPP-P3-CLI-Family Therapies and Group Therapies-11 Answer A is correct. As described by Bowen, a genogram is a diagram that summarizes important life events and other information about family members and their relationships for at least three generations.
column8: As described by Bowen, a genogram is a diagram that summarizes important life events and other information about family members and their relationships for at least three generations.
column10: A Bowenian extended family systems therapy practitioner uses a genogram to obtain information about the relationships among family members over multiple generations.

column3: Longitudinal research has found that the job satisfaction of individuals is:
column4: C. stable over time and across jobs and careers.
column5: EPPP-P3-ORG-Satisfaction, Commitment, and Stress-23 Answer C is correct. The research has found that a person's level of job satisfaction tends to be the same over time even when he/she changes jobs and careers (e.g., Staw, Bell, & Clausen, 1986).
column8: The research has found that a person's level of job satisfaction tends to be the same over time even when he/she changes jobs and careers (e.g., Staw, Bell, & Clausen, 1986).
column10: Longitudinal research has found that an individual's level of job satisfaction tends to be stable over time and across jobs and careers.

column3: Which of the following statements best describes the requirements of the ethics codes published by the American and Canadian Psychological Associations for bartering?
column4: C. Bartering may be acceptable when it's not clinically contraindicated.
column5: EPPP-P3-ETH-APA Ethics Code Standards 5 & 6-16 Answer C is correct. Bartering is addressed in Standard 6.05 of the APA Ethics Code and Standard III.28 of the Canadian Code of Ethics, which both prohibit bartering when it is "clinically contraindicated."
column8: Bartering is addressed in Standard 6.05 of the APA Ethics Code and Standard III.28 of the Canadian Code of Ethics, which both prohibit bartering when it is "clinically contraindicated."
column10: Bartering may be acceptable according to the ethics codes of the American and Canadian Psychological Associations when it is not clinically contraindicated.

column3: You've just moved to a new town and want to "drum up" business for your private practice. As an ethical psychologist, you will keep in mind that in-person solicitation of business:
column4: C. may be acceptable if it's uninvited as long as it does not target people who are vulnerable to undue influence.
column5: EPPP-P3-ETH-APA Ethics Code Standards 5 & 6-13 Answer C is correct. This issue is explicitly addressed in Standard 5.06 of the APA Ethics Code, which prohibits psychologists from engaging "in uninvited in-person solicitation of business from actual or potential therapy clients/patients or other persons who because of their particular circumstances are vulnerable to undue influence." This answer is also consistent with Standard I.27 of the Canadian Code of Ethics which requires that consent for professional services not be obtained "under any conditions of coercion, undue pressure, or undue reward." Note that answer D is not the best answer because it's too vague.
column8: This issue is explicitly addressed in Standard 5.06 of the APA Ethics Code, which prohibits psychologists from engaging "in uninvited in-person solicitation of business from actual or potential therapy clients/patients or other persons who because of their particular circumstances are vulnerable to undue influence." This answer is also consistent with Standard I.27 of the Canadian Code of Ethics which requires that consent for professional services not be obtained "under any conditions of coercion, undue pressure, or undue reward." Note that answer D is not the best answer because it's too vague.
column10: As an ethical psychologist, in-person solicitation of business may be acceptable if it is uninvited as long as it does not target people who are vulnerable to undue influence.

column3: Maslow's (1954) need hierarchy theory predicts that, when a person's physiological and safety needs have been satisfied, the person will be motivated primarily by his or her __________ needs.
column5: EPPP-P3-ORG-Theories of Motivation-21 Answer D is correct. Maslow's need hierarchy theory predicts that people have five basic needs that emerge in a hierarchical order that ranges from most basic to most complex, with behavior being motivated primarily by the lowest unfulfilled need. In order, the five needs are physiological, safety, social, esteem, and self-actualization.
column8: Maslow's need hierarchy theory predicts that people have five basic needs that emerge in a hierarchical order that ranges from most basic to most complex, with behavior being motivated primarily by the lowest unfulfilled need. In order, the five needs are physiological, safety, social, esteem, and self-actualization.
column10: Maslow's need hierarchy theory predicts that, when a person's physiological and safety needs have been satisfied, the person will be motivated primarily by their social needs.

column3: According to Moffitt (2003), the life-course persistent type of antisocial behavior is due to which of the following?
column5: EPPP-P3-PPA-Disruptive, Impulse-Control, and Conduct Disorders-24 Answer D is correct. Moffitt distinguishes between two types of antisocial behavior. The life-course persistent type is more serious and is the result of a combination of inherited or acquired neurological deficits and environmental risks, while the adolescence-limited type is due to a maturity gap, which is a gap between an adolescent's biological and social maturity. See, e.g., T. E. Moffitt, Life-course persistent and adolescence-limited antisocial behavior: A 10-year research review and research agenda, in B. B. Lahey, T. E. Moffitt, and A. Caspi (Eds.), Causes of conduct disorder and juvenile delinquency (pp. 49-75), New York, Guilford Press, 2003.
column8: Moffitt distinguishes between two types of antisocial behavior. The life-course persistent type is more serious and is the result of a combination of inherited or acquired neurological deficits and environmental risks, while the adolescence-limited type is due to a maturity gap, which is a gap between an adolescent's biological and social maturity. See, e.g., T. E. Moffitt, Life-course persistent and adolescence-limited antisocial behavior: A 10-year research review and research agenda, in B. B. Lahey, T. E. Moffitt, and A. Caspi (Eds.), Causes of conduct disorder and juvenile delinquency (pp. 49-75), New York, Guilford Press, 2003.
column10: According to Moffitt (2003), the life-course persistent type of antisocial behavior is the result of a combination of inherited or acquired neurological deficits and environmental risks.

column3: Which of the following is ordinarily one of the first self-conscious emotions to emerge?
column5: EPPP-P3-LIF-Socioemotional Development - Attachment, Emotions, and Social Relationships-20 Answer A is correct. Embarrassment, envy (jealousy), and empathy are the first self-conscious emotions to emerge at about 18 to 24 months of age. These emotions are followed by pride, shame, and guilt at about 30 to 36 months of age.
column7: Socioemotional Development - Attachment, Emotions, and Social Relationships
column8: Embarrassment, envy (jealousy), and empathy are the first self-conscious emotions to emerge at about 18 to 24 months of age. These emotions are followed by pride, shame, and guilt at about 30 to 36 months of age.
column10: Embarrassment, envy (jealousy), and empathy are the first self-conscious emotions to emerge at about 18 to 24 months of age.

column3: Sue and Sue (2015) illustrate the difference between which of the following by noting that twins who are raised together communicate more economically than two American lawyers do during a trial?
column5: EPPP-P3-CLI-Cross-Cultural Issues - Terms and Concepts-25 Answer A is correct. High-context communication relies heavily on group understanding, nonverbal messages, and the context in which the communication occurs, while low-context communication relies on the verbal message and is independent of the context (D. W. Sue and D. Sue, Counseling the culturally diverse: Theory and practice, Hoboken, NJ, John Wiley & Sons, 2015). Communication between twins raised together is likely to be high-context, while communication between two lawyers in a trial is likely to be low-context.
column8: High-context communication relies heavily on group understanding, nonverbal messages, and the context in which the communication occurs, while low-context communication relies on the verbal message and is independent of the context (D. W. Sue and D. Sue, Counseling the culturally diverse: Theory and practice, Hoboken, NJ, John Wiley & Sons, 2015). Communication between twins raised together is likely to be high-context, while communication between two lawyers in a trial is likely to be low-context.
column10: High-context communication relies heavily on group understanding, nonverbal messages, and the context in which the communication occurs, while low-context communication relies on the verbal message and is independent of the context, as illustrated by the difference in communication between twins raised together and two American lawyers during a trial.

column3: You would use the multivariate analysis of variance (MANOVA) to analyze the data you obtain in a research study when:
column4: D. your study includes two or more dependent variables that are measured on an interval or ratio scale.
column5: EPPP-P3-RMS-Inferential Statistical Tests-12 Answer D is correct. The MANOVA is used when a study includes one or more independent variables and two or more dependent variables that are each measured on an interval or ratio scale.
column8: The MANOVA is used when a study includes one or more independent variables and two or more dependent variables that are each measured on an interval or ratio scale.
column10: The multivariate analysis of variance (MANOVA) is used when a study includes one or more independent variables and two or more dependent variables that are each measured on an interval or ratio scale.

column3: Hovland and Sears (1940) found that, as the market price for cotton decreased between 1882 and 1930 in the Deep South, the number of lynchings of African American men increased. This result is best predicted by which of the following?
column5: EPPP-P3-SOC-Prosocial Behavior and Prejudice/Discrimination-14 Answer D is correct. C. Hovland and R. Sears concluded that the correlation they found between the market price of cotton and the incidence of lynching Black men confirmed their hypothesis that Black men became the targets of White men because White men were angry and frustrated because of the low market price of cotton in the Deep South (Minor studies of aggression: VI. Correlation of lynchings with economic conditions, The Journal of Psychology, 9, 301-310, 1940). Their conclusion is most consistent with scapegoat theory, which predicts that people tend to blame others for their own problems and is used to explain why members of a dominant group discriminate against or act aggressively toward members of a subordinate group. (Note that, while Hovland and Sears's conclusion has been used as an example of scapegoat theory, some investigators have challenged their research and the conclusion they drew from it on methodological grounds. For the exam, you do NOT need to be familiar with this challenge.)
column8: C. Hovland and R. Sears concluded that the correlation they found between the market price of cotton and the incidence of lynching Black men confirmed their hypothesis that Black men became the targets of White men because White men were angry and frustrated because of the low market price of cotton in the Deep South (Minor studies of aggression: VI. Correlation of lynchings with economic conditions, The Journal of Psychology, 9, 301-310, 1940). Their conclusion is most consistent with scapegoat theory, which predicts that people tend to blame others for their own problems and is used to explain why members of a dominant group discriminate against or act aggressively toward members of a subordinate group. (Note that, while Hovland and Sears's conclusion has been used as an example of scapegoat theory, some investigators have challenged their research and the conclusion they drew from it on methodological grounds. For the exam, you do NOT need to be familiar with this challenge.)
column10: Hovland and Sears (1940) found that, as the market price for cotton decreased between 1882 and 1930 in the Deep South, the number of lynchings of African American men increased, which is best predicted by scapegoat theory.

column3: Structural family therapists use which of the following to identify and alter the family's dysfunctional family structure and reassure family members that they're supported and understood?
column5: EPPP-P3-CLI-Family Therapies and Group Therapies-12 Answer B is correct. Joining involves entering the family system by adopting its behaviors and its communication style and content. Joining allows the therapist to develop a therapeutic alliance with family members and obtain the information needed to identify what changes should be made to the family's structure.
column8: Joining involves entering the family system by adopting its behaviors and its communication style and content. Joining allows the therapist to develop a therapeutic alliance with family members and obtain the information needed to identify what changes should be made to the family's structure.
column10: Structural family therapists use joining, which involves entering the family system by adopting its behaviors and its communication style and content, to identify and alter the family's dysfunctional family structure and reassure family members that they're supported and understood.

column3: When providing psychotherapy to employees through their company's employee assistance program (EAP), psychologists should let the employees know that:
column4: A. they will not release any confidential information to the employees' supervisors without the employees' authorization to do so.
column5: EPPP-P3-ETH-APA Ethics Code Standards 3 & 4-09 Answer A is correct. Clients of EAPs have the same right to confidentiality as other therapy clients do, and they should be reassured that confidential information will not be shared with their supervisors or employers without their authorization.
column8: Clients of EAPs have the same right to confidentiality as other therapy clients do, and they should be reassured that confidential information will not be shared with their supervisors or employers without their authorization.
column10: Psychologists should let employees using their company's employee assistance program (EAP) know that they will not release any confidential information to the employees' supervisors without the employees' authorization to do so.

column3: Ainsworth and her colleagues used the "strange situation" to study:
column5: EPPP-P3-LIF-Socioemotional Development - Attachment, Emotions, and Social Relationships-18 Answer B is correct. Ainsworth and her colleagues (Ainsworth, Blehar, Waters, & Wall, 1978) used the "strange situation" to study attachment in babies one to two years of age. It involves observing an infant during several brief episodes in which they're separated and reunited with their mothers.
column7: Socioemotional Development - Attachment, Emotions, and Social Relationships
column8: Ainsworth and her colleagues (Ainsworth, Blehar, Waters, & Wall, 1978) used the "strange situation" to study attachment in babies one to two years of age. It involves observing an infant during several brief episodes in which they're separated and reunited with their mothers.
column10: Ainsworth and her colleagues used the "strange situation" to study attachment in babies one to two years of age.

column3: Which of the following best describes the requirements of the ethics codes of the American and Canadian Psychological Associations regarding the release of test data and other client information to adult clients?
column4: C. Psychologists may refuse to release a client's test results to the client when they believe that doing so may cause imminent serious physical harm to the client.
column5: EPPP-P3-ETH-APA Ethics Code Standards 9 & 10-25 Answer C is correct. This answer is most consistent with the requirements of Standard 9.04 of the APA Ethics Code and Standard I.45 of the Canadian Code of Ethics. Standard 9.04(a) states that "psychologists may refrain from releasing test data to protect a client/patient or others from substantial harm or misuse or misrepresentation of the data or the test, recognizing that in many instances release of confidential information under these circumstances is regulated by law." And Standard I.45 states that psychologists may refrain from sharing confidential information "in circumstances of possible imminent serious bodily harm." Note that answer D is not the best answer because a client's lack of understanding of test results does not necessarily mean that releasing the results to the client will result in serious harm.
column8: This answer is most consistent with the requirements of Standard 9.04 of the APA Ethics Code and Standard I.45 of the Canadian Code of Ethics. Standard 9.04(a) states that "psychologists may refrain from releasing test data to protect a client/patient or others from substantial harm or misuse or misrepresentation of the data or the test, recognizing that in many instances release of confidential information under these circumstances is regulated by law." And Standard I.45 states that psychologists may refrain from sharing confidential information "in circumstances of possible imminent serious bodily harm." Note that answer D is not the best answer because a client's lack of understanding of test results does not necessarily mean that releasing the results to the client will result in serious harm.
column10: Psychologists may refuse to release a client's test results to the adult client when they believe that doing so may cause imminent serious physical harm to the client.

column3: When a parent, insurance company, or other third party is no longer willing to pay a client's fee for therapy and the client is unable to pay the full fee him/herself, a psychologist should do which of the following to be consistent with ethical requirements?
column4: C. provide pretermination counseling and referrals to alternative services
column5: EPPP-P3-ETH-APA Ethics Code Standards 9 & 10-26 Answer C is correct. Standard 10.10(c) of the APA Ethics Code and Standard II.34 of the Canadian Code of Ethics apply to this situation. Standard 10.10(c) states, "except where precluded by the actions of clients/patients or third-party payors, prior to termination psychologists provide pretermination counseling and suggest alternative service providers as appropriate." And Standard II.34 states that psychologists should provide clients "with reasonable assistance to find a way to receive needed services in the event that third party payments are exhausted and the primary client cannot afford the fees involved."
column8: Standard 10.10(c) of the APA Ethics Code and Standard II.34 of the Canadian Code of Ethics apply to this situation. Standard 10.10(c) states, "except where precluded by the actions of clients/patients or third-party payors, prior to termination psychologists provide pretermination counseling and suggest alternative service providers as appropriate." And Standard II.34 states that psychologists should provide clients "with reasonable assistance to find a way to receive needed services in the event that third party payments are exhausted and the primary client cannot afford the fees involved."
column10: When a parent, insurance company, or other third party is no longer willing to pay a client's fee for therapy and the client is unable to pay the full fee him/herself, a psychologist should provide pretermination counseling and referrals to alternative services.

column3: Abnormal levels of __________ have been linked to major depressive disorder with seasonal pattern.
column5: EPPP-P3-PPA-Bipolar and Depressive Disorders-08 Answer B is correct. Major depressive disorder with seasonal pattern is also known as seasonal affective disorder (SAD) and has been linked to a disruption in normal levels of melatonin, which is a hormone that's secreted by the pineal gland.
column8: Major depressive disorder with seasonal pattern is also known as seasonal affective disorder (SAD) and has been linked to a disruption in normal levels of melatonin, which is a hormone that's secreted by the pineal gland.
column10: Major depressive disorder with seasonal pattern, also known as seasonal affective disorder (SAD), has been linked to a disruption in normal levels of melatonin, a hormone secreted by the pineal gland.

column3: Consistent with evolutionary theory, the research has generally found that:
column4: A. men tend to be more upset by a partner's sexual infidelity, while women tend to be more upset by a partner's emotional infidelity.
column5: EPPP-P3-SOC-Affiliation, Attraction, and Intimacy-12 Answer A is correct. Buss, Larsen, Westen, and Semmelroth (1992) found that a partner's sexual and emotional infidelity elicit jealousy from both men and women, but that men respond more strongly to sexual infidelity, while women respond more strongly to emotional infidelity.
column8: Buss, Larsen, Westen, and Semmelroth (1992) found that a partner's sexual and emotional infidelity elicit jealousy from both men and women, but that men respond more strongly to sexual infidelity, while women respond more strongly to emotional infidelity.
column10: Consistent with evolutionary theory, research has generally found that men tend to be more upset by a partner's sexual infidelity, while women tend to be more upset by a partner's emotional infidelity.

column3: Which of the following individuals is at greatest risk for developing tardive dyskinesia?
column4: C. an older adult taking a conventional antipsychotic
column5: EPPP-P3-PHY-Psychopharmacology - Antipsychotics and Antidepressants-23 Answer C is correct. Tardive dyskinesia is caused by long-term use of an antipsychotic drug and involves repetitive involuntary movements of the tongue, face, neck, trunk, and extremities. The risk for tardive dyskinesia increases with increasing age; and, while conventional and atypical antipsychotics can both cause tardive dyskinesia, the risk is greater for conventional drugs.
column8: Tardive dyskinesia is caused by long-term use of an antipsychotic drug and involves repetitive involuntary movements of the tongue, face, neck, trunk, and extremities. The risk for tardive dyskinesia increases with increasing age; and, while conventional and atypical antipsychotics can both cause tardive dyskinesia, the risk is greater for conventional drugs.
column10: An older adult taking a conventional antipsychotic is at the greatest risk for developing tardive dyskinesia, a condition involving repetitive involuntary movements caused by long-term use of antipsychotic drugs.

column3: Response cost is an application of which of the following?
column5: EPPP-P3-LEA-Interventions Based on Operant Conditioning-10 Answer D is correct. Response cost is used to reduce or eliminate a behavior and does so by using negative punishment - i.e., by removing a positive reinforcer whenever the behavior occurs.
column8: Response cost is used to reduce or eliminate a behavior and does so by using negative punishment - i.e., by removing a positive reinforcer whenever the behavior occurs.
column10: Response cost is an application of negative punishment, which reduces or eliminates a behavior by removing a positive reinforcer whenever the behavior occurs.

column3: Practitioners of Milan systemic family therapy would be least likely to use which of the following techniques?
column5: EPPP-P3-CLI-Family Therapies and Group Therapies-13 Answer C is correct. Of the techniques listed in the answers, only fixed-role therapy is not associated with Milan systemic therapy. It's used by practitioners of Kelly's personal construct therapy and involves having clients adopt roles that will let them "try out" personal constructs that differ from their own.
column8: Of the techniques listed in the answers, only fixed-role therapy is not associated with Milan systemic therapy. It's used by practitioners of Kelly's personal construct therapy and involves having clients adopt roles that will let them "try out" personal constructs that differ from their own.
column10: Practitioners of Milan systemic family therapy would be least likely to use fixed-role therapy, which is associated with Kelly's personal construct therapy and involves having clients adopt roles to "try out" different personal constructs.

column3: The word COPYCAT is presented to a split-brain patient so that COPY is projected to the patient's left visual field and CAT is projected to his right visual field. When the patient is asked what he saw, the patient will say ________. And when the patient is asked to use his left hand to point to what he saw on a computer screen that contains the words COPY and CAT, the patient will point to ________.
column5: EPPP-P3-PHY-Brain Regions/Functions - Cerebral Cortex-06 Answer C is correct. COPY was projected to the patient's left visual field and went to his right hemisphere, while CAT was projected to the patient's right visual field and went to his left hemisphere. Because he's a split-brain patient, the two hemispheres are unable to communicate with each other. Consequently, the patient will say he saw the word CAT because the left hemisphere controls the production of language but will point to the word COPY because the right hemisphere controls the left hand.
column8: COPY was projected to the patient's left visual field and went to his right hemisphere, while CAT was projected to the patient's right visual field and went to his left hemisphere. Because he's a split-brain patient, the two hemispheres are unable to communicate with each other. Consequently, the patient will say he saw the word CAT because the left hemisphere controls the production of language but will point to the word COPY because the right hemisphere controls the left hand.
column10: A split-brain patient presented with the word "COPYCAT" will say "CAT" and point to "COPY" with their left hand, as the left visual field and right hemisphere cannot communicate with the right visual field and left hemisphere.

column3: Research has found that exposure to repetitive pain in early infancy:
column4: D. causes discomfort and increases future pain sensitivity.
column5: EPPP-P3-LIF-Physical Development-05 Answer D is correct. The studies have found that exposure to severe or repetitive pain during early infancy increases future sensitivity to pain and is associated with other adverse consequences (e.g., learning and behavioral problems in childhood). See, e.g., A. Mitchell and B. J. Boss, Adverse effects of pain on the nervous system of newborns and young children: A review of the literature, Journal of Neuroscience Nursing, 34, 228-235, 2002.
column8: The studies have found that exposure to severe or repetitive pain during early infancy increases future sensitivity to pain and is associated with other adverse consequences (e.g., learning and behavioral problems in childhood). See, e.g., A. Mitchell and B. J. Boss, Adverse effects of pain on the nervous system of newborns and young children: A review of the literature, Journal of Neuroscience Nursing, 34, 228-235, 2002.
column10: Exposure to severe or repetitive pain during early infancy increases future sensitivity to pain and is associated with other adverse consequences, such as learning and behavioral problems in childhood.

column3: Before using a selection test to estimate how well job applicants will do on a measure of job performance one year after they're hired, you would want to make sure the selection test has adequate:
column5: EPPP-P3-TES-Test Validity - Criterion-Related Validity-08 Answer A is correct. Evaluating a selection test's criterion-related validity is important when scores on the test (the predictor) will be used to estimate scores on a measure of performance (the criterion). There are two types of criterion-related validity: Concurrent validity is most important when the selection test will be used to estimate an applicant's current status on the criterion, while predictive validity is most important when the selection test will be used to estimate future status on the criterion.
column8: Evaluating a selection test's criterion-related validity is important when scores on the test (the predictor) will be used to estimate scores on a measure of performance (the criterion). There are two types of criterion-related validity: Concurrent validity is most important when the selection test will be used to estimate an applicant's current status on the criterion, while predictive validity is most important when the selection test will be used to estimate future status on the criterion.
column10: Evaluating a selection test's predictive validity is important when using the test scores to estimate an applicant's future job performance, as opposed to their current status.

column3: The most common early symptom of neurocognitive disorder due to Alzheimer's disease is:
column4: C. impaired memory for recent events.
column5: EPPP-P3-PPA-Neurocognitive Disorders--07 Answer C is correct. The most common early symptom of Alzheimer's disease is impaired memory for recent events. Perseveration (repetition of a word, phrase, or gesture) is most often identified as a characteristic of the middle stage. Although some authors describe it as beginning in the initial stage and then increasing significantly during the middle stage, it is not the best answer because it is not the most common early symptom. Sundowning (increased confusion, agitation, and restlessness in the late afternoon or evening) and disturbed sleep are characteristic of the middle stage.
column8: The most common early symptom of Alzheimer's disease is impaired memory for recent events. Perseveration (repetition of a word, phrase, or gesture) is most often identified as a characteristic of the middle stage. Although some authors describe it as beginning in the initial stage and then increasing significantly during the middle stage, it is not the best answer because it is not the most common early symptom. Sundowning (increased confusion, agitation, and restlessness in the late afternoon or evening) and disturbed sleep are characteristic of the middle stage.
column10: The most common early symptom of neurocognitive disorder due to Alzheimer's disease is impaired memory for recent events.

column3: Research on infantile amnesia has consistently found that:
column4: C. most older children and adults are unable to recall autobiographical events that occurred when they were less than three or four years of age.
column5: EPPP-P3-LIF-Cognitive Development-14 Answer C is correct. Infantile amnesia is also known as childhood amnesia and refers to the inability of older children, adolescents, and adults to recall events they experienced prior to three or four years of age. See, e.g., H. Hayne and G. Simcock, Memory development in toddlers, in M. L. Courage and N. Cowan (Eds.), The development of memory in infancy and childhood (pp. 43-68), New York, Psychology Press, 2009.
column8: Infantile amnesia is also known as childhood amnesia and refers to the inability of older children, adolescents, and adults to recall events they experienced prior to three or four years of age. See, e.g., H. Hayne and G. Simcock, Memory development in toddlers, in M. L. Courage and N. Cowan (Eds.), The development of memory in infancy and childhood (pp. 43-68), New York, Psychology Press, 2009.
column10: Research on infantile amnesia has consistently found that most older children and adults are unable to recall autobiographical events that occurred when they were less than three or four years of age.

column3: An infant with congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) is most likely to develop which of the following?
column5: EPPP-P3-LIF-Early Influences on Development - Prenatal Development-04 Answer B is correct. CMV is caused by exposure to a type of herpes virus during prenatal development. A small proportion of infants with CMV develop long-term problems, with sensorineural hearing loss being most common. See, e.g., J. F. Bale, Congenital cytomegalovirus infection, in M. J. Aminoff, F. Boller, and D. F. Swaab (Eds.), Handbook of clinical neurology (Vol. 123, pp. 319-326), Amsterdam, Elsevier, 2014.
column7: Early Influences on Development - Prenatal Development
column8: CMV is caused by exposure to a type of herpes virus during prenatal development. A small proportion of infants with CMV develop long-term problems, with sensorineural hearing loss being most common. See, e.g., J. F. Bale, Congenital cytomegalovirus infection, in M. J. Aminoff, F. Boller, and D. F. Swaab (Eds.), Handbook of clinical neurology (Vol. 123, pp. 319-326), Amsterdam, Elsevier, 2014.
column10: Congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) during prenatal development is most likely to cause sensorineural hearing loss in infants.

column3: Antisocial and histrionic personality disorders share several characteristics. In contrast to antisocial personality disorder, however, histrionic personality disorder is characterized by which of the following?
column5: EPPP-P3-PPA-Personality Disorders-29 Answer C is correct. The DSM-5 notes that antisocial and histrionic personality disorders share several characteristics including impulsivity, superficiality, and manipulativeness; however, people with histrionic personality disorder "tend to be more exaggerated in their emotions and do not characteristically engage in antisocial behaviors" (p. 669). In addition, people with histrionic personality disorder are manipulative in order to gain nurturance, while those with antisocial personality disorder are manipulative in order to gain power or material rewards.
column8: The DSM-5 notes that antisocial and histrionic personality disorders share several characteristics including impulsivity, superficiality, and manipulativeness; however, people with histrionic personality disorder "tend to be more exaggerated in their emotions and do not characteristically engage in antisocial behaviors" (p. 669). In addition, people with histrionic personality disorder are manipulative in order to gain nurturance, while those with antisocial personality disorder are manipulative in order to gain power or material rewards.
column10: Histrionic personality disorder, in contrast to antisocial personality disorder, is characterized by exaggerated expression of emotions.

column3: A test has a mean of 60 and standard deviation of 5, and test scores are normally distributed. Based on this information, you can conclude that about 95% of scores fall between scores of:
column5: EPPP-P3-RMS-Types of Variables and Data-02 Answer B is correct. In a normal distribution about 95% of scores fall between the scores that are plus and minus two standard deviations from the mean. This test has a mean of 60 and standard deviation of 5, so about 95% of scores fall between 60 plus and minus 10 (5 x 2), which is between 50 and 70.
column8: In a normal distribution about 95% of scores fall between the scores that are plus and minus two standard deviations from the mean. This test has a mean of 60 and standard deviation of 5, so about 95% of scores fall between 60 plus and minus 10 (5 x 2), which is between 50 and 70.
column10: In a normal distribution, about 95% of test scores with a mean of 60 and standard deviation of 5 fall between 50 and 70.

column3: A new selection test has ____________ validity when adding it to the existing selection procedure increases decision-making accuracy.
column5: EPPP-P3-ORG-Employee Selection - Evaluation of Techniques-07 Answer C is correct. Incremental validity refers to the increase in decision-making accuracy that occurs when a new selection technique is added to the existing selection procedure.
column8: Incremental validity refers to the increase in decision-making accuracy that occurs when a new selection technique is added to the existing selection procedure.
column10: Incremental validity refers to the increase in decision-making accuracy that occurs when a new selection technique is added to the existing selection procedure.

column3: The all-or-none law states that:
column4: D. the intensity of a nerve impulse is independent of stimulus intensity as long as the intensity reaches a minimum level.
column5: EPPP-P3-PHY-Nervous System, Neurons, and Neurotransmitters-12 Answer D is correct. According to the all-or-none law, once stimulus intensity reaches a minimum threshold, a nerve impulse (action potential) occurs. In other words, the intensity of a nerve impulse does not vary; instead, a nerve impulse either occurs or doesn't occur.
column8: According to the all-or-none law, once stimulus intensity reaches a minimum threshold, a nerve impulse (action potential) occurs. In other words, the intensity of a nerve impulse does not vary; instead, a nerve impulse either occurs or doesn't occur.
column10: According to the all-or-none law, the intensity of a nerve impulse is independent of stimulus intensity as long as the intensity reaches a minimum level.

column3: A rat is reinforced with a food pellet whenever it presses Bar A or presses Bar B. If reinforcement is stopped for pressing Bar B, the rat will:
column4: D. press Bar A with greater frequency and Bar B with less frequency.
column5: EPPP-P3-LEA-Operant Conditioning-07 Answer D is correct. This question is asking about behavioral contrast, which occurs when two behaviors are reinforced and reinforcement for one behavior is stopped. In this situation, the behavior that's still being reinforced increases in frequency, while the behavior that's no longer being reinforced decreases.
column8: This question is asking about behavioral contrast, which occurs when two behaviors are reinforced and reinforcement for one behavior is stopped. In this situation, the behavior that's still being reinforced increases in frequency, while the behavior that's no longer being reinforced decreases.
column10: If reinforcement is stopped for pressing Bar B, a rat will press Bar A with greater frequency and Bar B with less frequency.

column3: An assumption of classical test theory is that measurement error:
column5: EPPP-P3-TES-Item Analysis and Test Reliability-02 Answer A is correct. Classical test theory is based on the assumption that an examinee's obtained test score is due to a combination of "truth" and measurement error, with truth referring to the "true" amount of the characteristic measured by the test that the examinee has and measurement error being random (unsystematic).
column8: Classical test theory is based on the assumption that an examinee's obtained test score is due to a combination of "truth" and measurement error, with truth referring to the "true" amount of the characteristic measured by the test that the examinee has and measurement error being random (unsystematic).
column10: Classical test theory assumes that measurement error is random.

column3: Most babies exhibit a "vocabulary spurt" at about ___ months of age when they use about 50 words and thereafter acquire additional words very quickly.
column5: EPPP-P3-LIF-Language Development-09 Answer C is correct. The vocabulary spurt is also known as the vocabulary explosion and, for most babies, begins when they've mastered about 50 words which is usually around 18 months of age. See, e.g., D. W. Carroll, Psychology of language (5th ed.), Belmont, CA, Wadsworth, 2008.
column8: The vocabulary spurt is also known as the vocabulary explosion and, for most babies, begins when they've mastered about 50 words which is usually around 18 months of age. See, e.g., D. W. Carroll, Psychology of language (5th ed.), Belmont, CA, Wadsworth, 2008.
column10: The vocabulary spurt, when babies use about 50 words, usually begins around 18 months of age.

column3: A solution-focused therapist uses scaling questions to help clients:
column4: C. recognize the progress they've made toward achieving their goals.
column5: EPPP-P3-CLI-Brief Therapies-09 Answer C is correct. Scaling questions are used by solution-focused therapists to help clients evaluate their current status or their progress toward achieving their goals.
column8: Scaling questions are used by solution-focused therapists to help clients evaluate their current status or their progress toward achieving their goals.
column10: Solution-focused therapists use scaling questions to help clients recognize the progress they've made toward achieving their goals.

column3: You would use which of the following to teach each member of a team the essential tasks performed by other team members?
column5: EPPP-P3-ORG-Training Methods and Evaluation-10 Answer A is correct.Cross-training is a type of on-the-job training that involves teaching employees how to perform the essential tasks performed by other employees. It's often used as a method of training for team members.
column8: Cross-training is a type of on-the-job training that involves teaching employees how to perform the essential tasks performed by other employees. It's often used as a method of training for team members.
column10: Cross-training is a method used to teach each member of a team the essential tasks performed by other team members.

column3: When designing and conducting a research study, you can increase statistical power by doing which of the following?
column4: D. using a parametric test when it's appropriate to do so
column5: EPPP-P3-RMS-Overview of Inferential Statistics-09 Answer D is correct. Increasing the size of alpha, increasing the effect size (the magnitude of the effects of the independent variable), and using a parametric test when it's appropriate to do so are methods for increasing statistical power, which is the ability to reject a false null hypothesis. Randomly selecting subjects from the population increases a study's external validity but does not affect statistical power.
column8: Increasing the size of alpha, increasing the effect size (the magnitude of the effects of the independent variable), and using a parametric test when it's appropriate to do so are methods for increasing statistical power, which is the ability to reject a false null hypothesis. Randomly selecting subjects from the population increases a study's external validity but does not affect statistical power.
column10: Increasing the size of alpha, increasing the effect size, and using a parametric test when appropriate are methods for increasing the statistical power, which is the ability to reject a false null hypothesis, in designing and conducting a research study.

column3: Which of the following produces the most rapidly progressing neurocognitive disorder?
column5: EPPP-P3-PPA-Neurocognitive Disorders-28 Answer B is correct. Neurocognitive disorder due to Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease is categorized in DSM-5 as neurocognitive disorder due to prion disease and, like other prion diseases, typically progresses very rapidly. Most other types of neurocognitive disorders (including the three listed in the wrong answers to this question) have a gradual worsening of symptoms.
column8: Neurocognitive disorder due to Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease is categorized in DSM-5 as neurocognitive disorder due to prion disease and, like other prion diseases, typically progresses very rapidly. Most other types of neurocognitive disorders (including the three listed in the wrong answers to this question) have a gradual worsening of symptoms.
column10: Neurocognitive disorder due to Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, categorized in DSM-5 as neurocognitive disorder due to prion disease, typically progresses very rapidly compared to other types of neurocognitive disorders.

column3: According to Howard et al.'s (1986) dose-effect model, about ____% of therapy clients experience an improvement in symptoms by the 26th therapy session.
column5: EPPP-P3-CLI-Prevention, Consultation, and Psychotherapy Research-20 Answer C is correct. K. I. Howard, M. S. Krause, and D. E. Orlinsky found that about 50% of psychotherapy clients show improvement by the sixth to eighth therapy session, 75% by the 26th session, and 85% after a little over a year (The dose-effect relationship in psychotherapy, American Psychologist, 41, 159-164, 1986).
column8: K. I. Howard, M. S. Krause, and D. E. Orlinsky found that about 50% of psychotherapy clients show improvement by the sixth to eighth therapy session, 75% by the 26th session, and 85% after a little over a year (The dose-effect relationship in psychotherapy, American Psychologist, 41, 159-164, 1986).
column10: According to Howard et al.'s (1986) dose-effect model, about 75% of therapy clients experience an improvement in symptoms by the 26th therapy session.

column3: The dichotic listening task is used to obtain information about:
column5: EPPP-P3-PHY-Brain Regions/Functions - Cerebral Cortex-08 Answer B is correct. The dichotic listening task involves simultaneously presenting a person with two different auditory stimuli by delivering one stimulus to each ear. It's used to obtain information on selective auditory attention and hemispheric specialization for auditory stimuli.
column8: The dichotic listening task involves simultaneously presenting a person with two different auditory stimuli by delivering one stimulus to each ear. It's used to obtain information on selective auditory attention and hemispheric specialization for auditory stimuli.
column10: The dichotic listening task is used to obtain information about hemispheric specialization.

column3: Research has identified which of the Big Five personality traits to be the best predictor of job performance across different jobs and different measures of job performance?
column5: EPPP-P3-ORG-Employee Selection - Techniques-05 Answer A is correct. The Big Five personality traits are neuroticism, extraversion, agreeableness, conscientiousness, and openness to experience. Of these, conscientiousness has been found to be the best predictor of job performance across different jobs and performance criteria.
column8: The Big Five personality traits are neuroticism, extraversion, agreeableness, conscientiousness, and openness to experience. Of these, conscientiousness has been found to be the best predictor of job performance across different jobs and performance criteria.
column10: Of the Big Five personality traits, conscientiousness has been found to be the best predictor of job performance across different jobs and performance criteria.

column3: The research has found that, when people estimate the frequency of a particular event, they tend to give more weight to anecdotal information about that event than to statistical data. This is referred to as:
column5: EPPP-P3-SOC-Social Cognition - Errors, Biases, and Heuristics-02 Answer D is correct: The base rate fallacy is the tendency to be influenced more by information about an individual case (e.g., anecdotal information about a single event) than by base rate data.
column7: Social Cognition - Errors, Biases, and Heuristics
column8: : The base rate fallacy is the tendency to be influenced more by information about an individual case (e.g., anecdotal information about a single event) than by base rate data.
column10: The base rate fallacy is the tendency to be influenced more by information about an individual case than by base rate data when estimating the frequency of a particular event.

column3: The nonpharmacological treatment for a patient with insomnia disorder will most likely include which of the following?
column5: EPPP-P3-PPA-Feeding/Eating, Elimination, and Sleep-Wake Disorders-21 Answer B is correct.The nonpharmacological treatment-of-choice for insomnia disorder is a multi-component cognitive-behavioral intervention that incorporates stimulus control or sleep restriction with sleep-hygiene education, relaxation training, and/or cognitive therapy.
column8: The nonpharmacological treatment-of-choice for insomnia disorder is a multi-component cognitive-behavioral intervention that incorporates stimulus control or sleep restriction with sleep-hygiene education, relaxation training, and/or cognitive therapy.
column10: The nonpharmacological treatment-of-choice for insomnia disorder is a multi-component cognitive-behavioral intervention that incorporates stimulus control or sleep restriction with sleep-hygiene education, relaxation training, and/or cognitive therapy.

column3: Studies conducted to identify the change mechanisms responsible for the positive effects of mindfulness-based interventions have generally found which of the following to be the most likely mechanism?
column4: C. decreased cognitive and emotional reactivity
column5: EPPP-P3-CLI-Cognitive-Behavioral Therapies-02 Answer C is correct. The results of the frequently cited systematic review and meta-analysis of the research conducted by Gu et al. (2015) found decreases in cognitive and emotional reactivity to have the strongest and most consistent evidence as the change mechanism for mindfulness-based interventions.
column8: The results of the frequently cited systematic review and meta-analysis of the research conducted by Gu et al. (2015) found decreases in cognitive and emotional reactivity to have the strongest and most consistent evidence as the change mechanism for mindfulness-based interventions.
column10: The results of the frequently cited systematic review and meta-analysis of the research conducted by Gu et al. (2015) found decreases in cognitive and emotional reactivity to have the strongest and most consistent evidence as the change mechanism for mindfulness-based interventions.

column3: ____________ review of the psychotherapy outcome research indicated that people who participate in psychotherapy often show less improvement than do people with similar symptoms who do not participate in therapy.
column5: EPPP-P3-CLI-Prevention, Consultation, and Psychotherapy Research-22 Answer D is correct. Based on his review of the research, Eysenck (1952) concluded that 44% of patients who received psychodynamic psychotherapy and 66% of patients who received eclectic therapy showed an improvement in symptoms, while 72% of patients with similar initial symptoms who did not receive psychotherapy improved.
column8: Based on his review of the research, Eysenck (1952) concluded that 44% of patients who received psychodynamic psychotherapy and 66% of patients who received eclectic therapy showed an improvement in symptoms, while 72% of patients with similar initial symptoms who did not receive psychotherapy improved.
column10: Eysenck's review of the psychotherapy outcome research indicated that people who participate in psychotherapy often show less improvement than do people with similar symptoms who do not participate in therapy.

column3: While developing a training program, an organizational psychologist administers each component of the program to a sample of newly hired employees. After delivering each component, the psychologist has the employees complete questionnaires to evaluate their satisfaction with the program and acquisition of information to determine if the component needs revision. The psychologist is conducting which type of evaluation?
column5: EPPP-P3-ORG-Training Methods and Evaluation-11 Answer B is correct. A formative evaluation is conducted during the development of a training program to determine what changes need to be made for the program to achieve its goals. It may include having experts review the content of each component of the program to determine if it matches program goals and administering measures of attitudes and learning to trainees following delivery of each component.
column8: A formative evaluation is conducted during the development of a training program to determine what changes need to be made for the program to achieve its goals. It may include having experts review the content of each component of the program to determine if it matches program goals and administering measures of attitudes and learning to trainees following delivery of each component.
column10: A formative evaluation is conducted during the development of a training program to determine what changes need to be made for the program to achieve its goals, and it may include having experts review the content of each component of the program and administering measures of attitudes and learning to trainees following delivery of each component.

column3: You are conducting a research study that involves administering several tests to middle school students. Before starting the study, you obtained informed consents from the students and their parents but, during the course of the study, three of the students say they don't want to take all of the tests. As an ethical psychologist, you:
column4: D. allow the students to withdraw from the study.
column5: EPPP-P3-ETH-APA Ethics Code Standards 7 & 8-18 Answer D is correct. Standard 8.02 of the APA Ethics Code and Standard I.23 of the Canadian Code of Ethics both require psychologists to allow research participants to withdraw from research at any time. Trying to coerce the students to participate would be unethical.
column8: Standard 8.02 of the APA Ethics Code and Standard I.23 of the Canadian Code of Ethics both require psychologists to allow research participants to withdraw from research at any time. Trying to coerce the students to participate would be unethical.
column10: The APA Ethics Code and Canadian Code of Ethics require psychologists to allow research participants to withdraw from a study at any time, so an ethical psychologist would allow the students to withdraw from the study.

column3: Drugs that reduce __________ activity in certain areas of the brain have been found useful for suppressing tics.
column5: EPPP-P3-PPA-Neurodevelopmental Disorders-03 Answer B is correct. Knowing that antipsychotic drugs are used to treat tic disorders and that they exert their therapeutic effects by blocking dopamine receptors would have helped you identify dopamine as the correct answer to this question.
column8: Knowing that antipsychotic drugs are used to treat tic disorders and that they exert their therapeutic effects by blocking dopamine receptors would have helped you identify dopamine as the correct answer to this question.
column10: Antipsychotic drugs that reduce dopamine activity in certain areas of the brain have been found useful for suppressing tics.

column3: A scatterplot is constructed from the scores obtained by a sample of employees on a newly developed selection test (X) and a measure of job performance (Y). The scatterplot indicates that the variability of Y scores is about the same for all scores on X. Which of the following terms describes this situation?
column5: EPPP-P3-RMS-Correlation and Regression-07 Answer A is correct. The terms homoscedasticity and heteroscedasticity are used to describe the relationship between two variables in terms of the amount of variability in one variable for different values of the other variable. Homoscedasticity occurs when the variability of scores on one variable is about the same at different values of the other variable; heteroscedasticity occurs when the variability of scores on one variable differs at different values of the other variable. Homoscedasticity is one of the conditions that tends to increase the correlation coefficient. Also, when data are homoscedastic, the use of a regression equation to predict people's scores on Y from their scores on X will produce the same accuracy of prediction for all scores on X.
column8: The terms homoscedasticity and heteroscedasticity are used to describe the relationship between two variables in terms of the amount of variability in one variable for different values of the other variable. Homoscedasticity occurs when the variability of scores on one variable is about the same at different values of the other variable; heteroscedasticity occurs when the variability of scores on one variable differs at different values of the other variable. Homoscedasticity is one of the conditions that tends to increase the correlation coefficient. Also, when data are homoscedastic, the use of a regression equation to predict people's scores on Y from their scores on X will produce the same accuracy of prediction for all scores on X.
column10: A scatterplot showing that the variability of Y scores is about the same for all scores on X indicates a situation of homoscedasticity.

column3: The use of in vivo exposure to treat a specific phobia is based on the assumption that the feared object or situation is a(n):
column5: EPPP-P3-LEA-Interventions Based on Classical Conditioning-05 Answer B is correct. In vivo exposure for specific phobia is based on the assumption that the object or situation that produces the phobic response is a conditioned stimulus - i.e., that, at some time in the past, the object or situation was paired with an unconditioned stimulus that naturally elicits a fear response. In vivo exposure involves repeatedly presenting the conditioned stimulus without the unconditioned stimulus in order to extinguish the conditioned fear response.
column8: In vivo exposure for specific phobia is based on the assumption that the object or situation that produces the phobic response is a conditioned stimulus - i.e., that, at some time in the past, the object or situation was paired with an unconditioned stimulus that naturally elicits a fear response. In vivo exposure involves repeatedly presenting the conditioned stimulus without the unconditioned stimulus in order to extinguish the conditioned fear response.
column10: The use of in vivo exposure to treat a specific phobia is based on the assumption that the feared object or situation is a conditioned stimulus.

column3: Empirical criterion keying was used to develop the clinical scales of the MMPI-2. This involved including items in the scales that:
column4: A. distinguished between clinical groups and a general (nonclinical) group.
column5: EPPP-P3-PAS-MMPI-2-01 Answer A is correct. When using empirical criterion keying to develop scales, items that distinguish between relevant groups are included in each scale. For the MMPI-2 clinical scales, the responses of groups of patients who had received the relevant diagnoses were compared to the responses of a group consisting of members of the general population.
column8: When using empirical criterion keying to develop scales, items that distinguish between relevant groups are included in each scale. For the MMPI-2 clinical scales, the responses of groups of patients who had received the relevant diagnoses were compared to the responses of a group consisting of members of the general population.
column10: Empirical criterion keying was used to develop the clinical scales of the MMPI-2 by including items that distinguished between clinical groups and a general (nonclinical) group.

column3: Anna just started college and is certain that students in her classes already think she's stupid even though they're nice to her and a few have attempted to become friends. For a practitioner of Beck's cognitive-behavior therapy, Anna's conclusion is an example of which of the following?
column5: EPPP-P3-CLI-Cognitive-Behavioral Therapies-16 Answer C is correct. Arbitrary inference is one of the cognitive distortions identified by Beck. It occurs when a person draws a conclusion without having evidence to support it.
column8: Arbitrary inference is one of the cognitive distortions identified by Beck. It occurs when a person draws a conclusion without having evidence to support it.
column10: Anna's conclusion that students in her classes already think she's stupid is an example of arbitrary inference, a cognitive distortion identified by Beck.

column3: Dr. O'Leary, a neuropsychologist, administers a number of tests to new patients with traumatic brain injury to assist with differential diagnosis and treatment planning. She decides to also use her patients' test data in a research study she will be conducting on the effects of traumatic brain injury on memory. In terms of ethical requirements, this is:
column4: C. unacceptable unless she gets the patients' consent to use their test information in the research study.
column5: EPPP-P3-ETH-APA Ethics Code Standards 9 & 10-22 Answer C is correct. This answer is most consistent with the requirements of Standard 9.03(a) of the APA Ethics Code and Standard I.23 of the Canadian Code of Ethics, which require informed consents for assessment to include a description of the purpose of the assessment. Dr. O'Leary originally administered the tests for the purpose of diagnosis and treatment planning (and presumably obtained consent from her patients for that purpose) and she must also obtain consent to include their test data in her research study.
column8: This answer is most consistent with the requirements of Standard 9.03(a) of the APA Ethics Code and Standard I.23 of the Canadian Code of Ethics, which require informed consents for assessment to include a description of the purpose of the assessment. Dr. O'Leary originally administered the tests for the purpose of diagnosis and treatment planning (and presumably obtained consent from her patients for that purpose) and she must also obtain consent to include their test data in her research study.
column10: An ethical psychologist must obtain the patients' consent to use their test information in a research study, in addition to the consent obtained for the initial assessment.

column3: The parents of 10-year-old Corey bring him to therapy at the recommendation of his school counselor who is concerned about his increasing oppositional behavior and failing grades. You decide that you will initially see Corey in individual therapy. To be consistent with ethical requirements you will do which of the following?
column4: A. obtain written consent from Corey's parents and verbal assent from Corey as soon as possible
column5: EPPP-P3-ETH-APA Ethics Code Standards 9 & 10-27 Answer A is correct. Obtaining informed consent from Corey's parents and assent from Corey is consistent with the requirements of Standard 3.10 of the APA Ethics Code and Standard I.34 of the Canadian Code of Ethics, and obtaining consent and assent as soon as possible is consistent with the requirements of Standard 10.01 of the APA Ethics Code and Standard I.19 of the Canadian Code of Ethics. For example, Standard 3.10 requires that, for people who aren't legally capable of giving consent, psychologists seek their assent and permission from a legally authorized person, while Standard 10.01(a) requires psychologists to obtain informed consents "as early as is feasible."
column8: Obtaining informed consent from Corey's parents and assent from Corey is consistent with the requirements of Standard 3.10 of the APA Ethics Code and Standard I.34 of the Canadian Code of Ethics, and obtaining consent and assent as soon as possible is consistent with the requirements of Standard 10.01 of the APA Ethics Code and Standard I.19 of the Canadian Code of Ethics. For example, Standard 3.10 requires that, for people who aren't legally capable of giving consent, psychologists seek their assent and permission from a legally authorized person, while Standard 10.01(a) requires psychologists to obtain informed consents "as early as is feasible."
column10: To be consistent with ethical requirements, a psychologist must obtain written consent from a child's parents and verbal assent from the child as soon as possible when seeing the child in individual therapy.

column3: Studies using functional neuroimaging techniques have found that which of the following areas of the brain is essential for prospective memory?
column5: EPPP-P3-PHY-Memory and Sleep-16 Answer C is correct. Prospective memory is memory for things that must be done in the future (e.g., remembering that you have to pick up a friend at the airport at 10 am next Saturday). Studies using functional neuroimaging techniques have found that activity in the prefrontal cortex increases when individuals perform prospective memory tasks. Other areas of the brain that play a role in prospective memory include the parietal lobe, hippocampus, anterior cingulate cortex, and thalamus.
column8: Prospective memory is memory for things that must be done in the future (e.g., remembering that you have to pick up a friend at the airport at 10 am next Saturday). Studies using functional neuroimaging techniques have found that activity in the prefrontal cortex increases when individuals perform prospective memory tasks. Other areas of the brain that play a role in prospective memory include the parietal lobe, hippocampus, anterior cingulate cortex, and thalamus.
column10: Studies using functional neuroimaging techniques have found that the prefrontal cortex is essential for prospective memory.

column3: To evaluate the effectiveness of a stress reduction technique for alleviating test anxiety, a psychologist administers a measure of test anxiety to Psychology 101 undergraduates, chooses the 50 students with the highest scores on the test, administers the intervention to the students, and then readministers the measure of test anxiety. The biggest threat to this study's internal validity is:
column5: EPPP-P3-RMS-Research - Internal/External Validity-03 Answer C is correct. Whenever subjects are chosen for inclusion in a study because they have extreme scores on the pretest, their scores on the posttest are likely to "regress toward the mean" regardless of the effects of the independent variable. This is referred to as statistical regression, and it threatens a study's internal validity whenever it's not possible to ascertain to what extent a change in posttest scores is due to statistical regression or the effects of the independent variable.
column8: Whenever subjects are chosen for inclusion in a study because they have extreme scores on the pretest, their scores on the posttest are likely to "regress toward the mean" regardless of the effects of the independent variable. This is referred to as statistical regression, and it threatens a study's internal validity whenever it's not possible to ascertain to what extent a change in posttest scores is due to statistical regression or the effects of the independent variable.
column10: The biggest threat to the internal validity of a study evaluating the effectiveness of a stress reduction technique for alleviating test anxiety is statistical regression.

column3: Following a closed head injury caused by a fall down a flight of stairs, a 54-year-old woman experiences retrograde amnesia for events that occurred during the five years prior to her fall. When her memories begin to return, she will likely remember which of the following first?
column4: A. the family reunion she attended 4-1/2 years ago
column5: EPPP-P3-PHY-Neurological and Endocrine Disorders-21 Answer A is correct. The recovery of long-term memories following a traumatic brain injury ordinarily involves "shrinking retrograde amnesia" in which more distant (remote) memories are recovered first.
column8: The recovery of long-term memories following a traumatic brain injury ordinarily involves "shrinking retrograde amnesia" in which more distant (remote) memories are recovered first.
column10: A 54-year-old woman with retrograde amnesia following a closed head injury will likely remember the family reunion she attended 4-1/2 years ago first as the recovery of long-term memories following a traumatic brain injury ordinarily involves "shrinking retrograde amnesia" in which more distant (remote) memories are recovered first.

column3: Linking the requirements for successful job performance to organizational values, goals, and strategies is characteristic of which of the following?
column5: EPPP-P3-ORG-Job Analysis and Performance Assessment-01 Answer C is correct. Competency modeling is similar to job analysis but focuses on the core competencies that are required to successfully perform all jobs or a subset of jobs within an organization and are linked to the organization's values, goals, and strategies.
column8: Competency modeling is similar to job analysis but focuses on the core competencies that are required to successfully perform all jobs or a subset of jobs within an organization and are linked to the organization's values, goals, and strategies.
column10: Competency modeling is similar to job analysis but focuses on the core competencies that are required to successfully perform all jobs or a subset of jobs within an organization and are linked to the organization's values, goals, and strategies.

column3: _____________ is the appropriate method for combining scores on several selection tests when a high score on one or more tests can compensate for a low score on another test.
column5: EPPP-P3-ORG-Employee Selection - Techniques-06 Answer C is correct. Multiple regression is a compensatory method for combining predictor scores that involves weighting each predictor on the basis of its correlations with the other predictors and with the criterion and then combining the weighted predictor scores to obtain an estimated criterion score. This makes it possible for a high score on one or more predictors to compensate for a low score on another predictor. Multiple hurdle and multiple cutoff are noncompensatory methods.
column8: Multiple regression is a compensatory method for combining predictor scores that involves weighting each predictor on the basis of its correlations with the other predictors and with the criterion and then combining the weighted predictor scores to obtain an estimated criterion score. This makes it possible for a high score on one or more predictors to compensate for a low score on another predictor. Multiple hurdle and multiple cutoff are noncompensatory methods.
column10: Multiple regression is a compensatory method for combining predictor scores that involves weighting each predictor on the basis of its correlations with the other predictors and with the criterion and then combining the weighted predictor scores to obtain an estimated criterion score, making it possible for a high score on one or more predictors to compensate for a low score on another predictor.

column3: The treatment-of-choice for agoraphobia is in vivo exposure with:
column5: EPPP-P3-PPA-Anxiety Disorders and Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder-12 Answer A is correct. In vivo exposure and response prevention is considered the first-line treatment for agoraphobia, and the research has found that combining exposure with applied relaxation, breathing retraining, or cognitive techniques does not significantly improve outcomes.
column8: In vivo exposure and response prevention is considered the first-line treatment for agoraphobia, and the research has found that combining exposure with applied relaxation, breathing retraining, or cognitive techniques does not significantly improve outcomes.
column10: In vivo exposure and response prevention is considered the first-line treatment for agoraphobia, and the research has found that combining exposure with applied relaxation, breathing retraining, or cognitive techniques does not significantly improve outcomes.

column3: A psychotherapist is careful not to overuse traditional Western psychotherapeutic interventions with clients from cultural minority groups because she believes that culture impacts psychiatric symptoms and responses to interventions. This therapist has adopted which of the following perspectives?
column5: EPPP-P3-CLI-Cross-Cultural Issues - Terms and Concepts-24 Answer D is correct. A therapist who has an etic perspective believes that culture has little or no impact on diagnosis and treatment, while a therapist who has an emic perspective believes that culture affects how psychological symptoms are experienced and expressed and how clients respond to therapeutic interventions.
column8: A therapist who has an etic perspective believes that culture has little or no impact on diagnosis and treatment, while a therapist who has an emic perspective believes that culture affects how psychological symptoms are experienced and expressed and how clients respond to therapeutic interventions.
column10: A therapist who has an emic perspective believes that culture affects how psychological symptoms are experienced and expressed and how clients respond to therapeutic interventions.

column3: Which of the following best describes a psychologist's ethical obligations with regard to the use of automated test scoring and interpretation services?
column4: A. Psychologists who use these services are responsible for the validity of the conclusions they derive from them.
column5: EPPP-P3-ETH-APA Ethics Code Standards 9 & 10-23 Answer A is correct. The use of automated scoring and interpretation services is not discouraged or prohibited by ethical guidelines, and their validity is directly addressed in Standard 9.09(c) of the APA Ethics Code and indirectly addressed in Standard II.3 of the Canadian Code of Ethics. Standard 9.09(c) states that "psychologists retain responsibility for the appropriate application, interpretation, and use of assessment instruments, whether they score and interpret such tests themselves or use automated or other services." And Standard II.3 states that psychologists "accept responsibility for the consequences of their actions."
column8: The use of automated scoring and interpretation services is not discouraged or prohibited by ethical guidelines, and their validity is directly addressed in Standard 9.09(c) of the APA Ethics Code and indirectly addressed in Standard II.3 of the Canadian Code of Ethics. Standard 9.09(c) states that "psychologists retain responsibility for the appropriate application, interpretation, and use of assessment instruments, whether they score and interpret such tests themselves or use automated or other services." And Standard II.3 states that psychologists "accept responsibility for the consequences of their actions."
column10: Psychologists who use automated scoring and interpretation services are responsible for the validity of the conclusions they derive from them.

column3: Which of the following is not used to treat genito-pelvic pain disorder?
column5: EPPP-P3-PPA-Sexual Dysfunctions, Gender Dysphoria, and Paraphilic Disorders-22 Answer D is correct. Interventions for genito-pelvic pain disorder include relaxation training, sensate focus, a topical anesthetic, vaginal dilators, and Kegel exercises. Orgasmic reconditioning is used to treat paraphilic disorders.
column7: Sexual Dysfunctions, Gender Dysphoria, and Paraphilic Disorders
column8: Interventions for genito-pelvic pain disorder include relaxation training, sensate focus, a topical anesthetic, vaginal dilators, and Kegel exercises. Orgasmic reconditioning is used to treat paraphilic disorders.
column10: Interventions for genito-pelvic pain disorder include relaxation training, sensate focus, a topical anesthetic, vaginal dilators, and Kegel exercises, but orgasmic reconditioning is used to treat paraphilic disorders.

column3: A research study found that in-group members consistently attributed the behaviors of out-group members to dispositional factors when the behaviors produced bad outcomes, but consistently attributed the behaviors of out-group members to situational factors when they produced good outcomes. This result is consistent with which of the following?
column5: EPPP-P3-SOC-Social Cognition - Causal Attributions-01 Answer C is correct. The ultimate attribution error applies to attributions made about members of an entire group. It occurs when members of an in-group consistently attribute the negative outcomes of out-group members to dispositional factors and their positive outcomes to situational factors.
column8: The ultimate attribution error applies to attributions made about members of an entire group. It occurs when members of an in-group consistently attribute the negative outcomes of out-group members to dispositional factors and their positive outcomes to situational factors.
column10: The ultimate attribution error applies to attributions made about members of an entire group, where members of an in-group consistently attribute the negative outcomes of out-group members to dispositional factors and their positive outcomes to situational factors.

column3: __________ is used to establish a complex behavior that consists of a sequence of components by establishing the components one at a time.
column5: EPPP-P3-LEA-Interventions Based on Operant Conditioning-11 Answer A is correct. Chaining is used to establish a complex behavior that consists of a sequence of responses that occur in a fixed order. In contrast, shaping is used to establish a behavior by reinforcing successive approximations to (not components of) the behavior.
column8: Chaining is used to establish a complex behavior that consists of a sequence of responses that occur in a fixed order. In contrast, shaping is used to establish a behavior by reinforcing successive approximations to (not components of) the behavior.
