column10: Chaining is used to establish a complex behavior that consists of a sequence of responses that occur in a fixed order, in contrast to shaping, which is used to establish a behavior by reinforcing successive approximations to (not components of) the behavior.

column3: When acting as a fact witness in a legal proceeding, psychologists:
column4: A. cannot offer their opinions about a defendant's mental state.
column5: EPPP-P3-ETH-APA Ethics Code Standards 9 & 10-28 Answer A is correct. Fact witnesses testify about the facts (what they have observed), while expert witnesses offer opinions.
column8: Fact witnesses testify about the facts (what they have observed), while expert witnesses offer opinions.
column10: When acting as a fact witness in a legal proceeding, psychologists cannot offer their opinions about a defendant's mental state, as fact witnesses testify about the facts (what they have observed), while expert witnesses offer opinions.

column3: Based on the results of his research, Meyer (2003) concluded that members of LGB populations have higher rates of mental disorders than members of the heterosexual population as a result of which of the following?
column5: EPPP-P3-CLI-Cross-Cultural Issues - Terms and Concepts-26 Answer A is correct. I. H. Meyer concluded that the higher prevalence rates of mental disorders among members of LGB populations are due to minority stress - i.e., from exposure to "stigma, prejudice, and discrimination  [which creates] a hostile and stressful social environment that causes mental health problems" [Prejudice, social stress, and mental health in lesbian, gay, and bisexual populations: Conceptual issues and research evidence, Psychological Bulletin, 129(5), 674-697, 2003, p. 674].
column8: I. H. Meyer concluded that the higher prevalence rates of mental disorders among members of LGB populations are due to minority stress - i.e., from exposure to "stigma, prejudice, and discrimination  [which creates] a hostile and stressful social environment that causes mental health problems" [Prejudice, social stress, and mental health in lesbian, gay, and bisexual populations: Conceptual issues and research evidence, Psychological Bulletin, 129(5), 674-697, 2003, p. 674].
column10: Meyer concluded that higher prevalence rates of mental disorders among members of LGB populations are due to minority stress - i.e., exposure to stigma, prejudice, and discrimination which creates a hostile and stressful social environment that causes mental health problems.

column3: Helms's (1995) model of White racial identity development predicts that a White therapist in which of the following stages is likely to be most effective when working with clients from racial or ethnic minority groups?
column5: EPPP-P3-CLI-Cross-Cultural Issues - Identity Development Models-28 Answer B is correct. Helms's model of White racial identity development distinguishes between six stages: contact, disintegration, reintegration, pseudo-independence, immersion-emersion, and autonomy. A White therapist in the final stage (autonomy) has non-racist attitudes and a stable White identity that's not rooted in privilege and is likely to be more effective than White therapists in other stages when working with clients from racial or ethnic minority groups.
column8: Helms's model of White racial identity development distinguishes between six stages: contact, disintegration, reintegration, pseudo-independence, immersion-emersion, and autonomy. A White therapist in the final stage (autonomy) has non-racist attitudes and a stable White identity that's not rooted in privilege and is likely to be more effective than White therapists in other stages when working with clients from racial or ethnic minority groups.
column10: A White therapist in the final "autonomy" stage of Helms's model of White racial identity development has non-racist attitudes and a stable White identity not rooted in privilege, and is likely to be more effective when working with clients from racial or ethnic minority groups.

column3: When you assess the validity of a test, you are assessing its:
column5: EPPP-P3-TES-Test Validity - Content and Construct Validity-05 Answer A is correct. A test is valid to the extent that it accurately measures what it was designed to measure, and the different methods for evaluating a test's validity are different methods for assessing accuracy.
column7: Test Validity - Content and Construct Validity
column8: A test is valid to the extent that it accurately measures what it was designed to measure, and the different methods for evaluating a test's validity are different methods for assessing accuracy.
column10: Assessing the validity of a test means evaluating its accuracy in measuring what it was designed to measure.

column3: Byrne's (1971) law of attraction identifies which of the following as an explanation for the positive relationship between attitude similarity and interpersonal attraction?
column5: EPPP-P3-SOC-Affiliation, Attraction, and Intimacy-11 Answer B is correct. Byrne's (1971) law of attraction states that there's a positive relationship between attitude similarity and attraction and that this relationship is due to the fact that interacting with people who have similar attitudes is reinforcing because it validates one's views and produces good feelings.
column8: Byrne's (1971) law of attraction states that there's a positive relationship between attitude similarity and attraction and that this relationship is due to the fact that interacting with people who have similar attitudes is reinforcing because it validates one's views and produces good feelings.
column10: Byrne's law of attraction states that the positive relationship between attitude similarity and interpersonal attraction is due to the reinforcing effect of interacting with people who have similar attitudes, as it validates one's views and produces good feelings.

column3: Dr. Liu, a licensed psychologist, is asked by a local television station if she would be interested in participating in a 10-minute segment every week during the Monday morning news show. The station would like her to present a four- to five-minute summary of a different mental health issue each week and then respond to emails and calls from viewers for the remaining time. If Dr. Liu accepts the offer to participate in the program, she:
column4: B. will have acted unethically unless she makes sure that viewers understand that her responses to their emails and calls do not establish a therapeutic relationship.
column5: EPPP-P3-ETH-APA Ethics Code Standards 5 & 6-15 Answer B is correct. This situation is directly addressed in Standard 5.04 of the APA Ethics Code and indirectly in Standard III.5 of the Canadian Code of Ethics. In this situation, a psychologist would want to make sure that viewers understand that a professional therapeutic relationship is not established when he/she responds to their questions and that his/her advice does not constitute therapy.
column8: This situation is directly addressed in Standard 5.04 of the APA Ethics Code and indirectly in Standard III.5 of the Canadian Code of Ethics. In this situation, a psychologist would want to make sure that viewers understand that a professional therapeutic relationship is not established when he/she responds to their questions and that his/her advice does not constitute therapy.
column10: Unless a psychologist clearly communicates that responding to viewer emails and calls does not establish a therapeutic relationship, accepting an offer to present mental health information on a TV program would be unethical.

column3: When relying on the anchoring and adjustment heuristic, the "anchor" is:
column5: EPPP-P3-SOC-Social Cognition - Errors, Biases, and Heuristics-03 Answer C is correct. When using the anchoring and adjustment heuristic, people estimate the frequency of an event or other value by beginning with a starting point (the anchor) and then making upward or downward adjustments. For example, when negotiating the price of a used bicycle at a garage sale, the seller's initial price is the starting point and determines the size of the purchaser's counteroffer.
column7: Social Cognition - Errors, Biases, and Heuristics
column8: When using the anchoring and adjustment heuristic, people estimate the frequency of an event or other value by beginning with a starting point (the anchor) and then making upward or downward adjustments. For example, when negotiating the price of a used bicycle at a garage sale, the seller's initial price is the starting point and determines the size of the purchaser's counteroffer.
column10: The "anchor" in the anchoring and adjustment heuristic is the starting point from which people estimate the frequency of an event or other value and then make upward or downward adjustments.

column3: At a company party, you first meet a co-worker's husband whose name is Bill. About twenty minutes later, you meet another co-worker's husband whose name is Bob. Then, about an hour later, you encounter Bill at the buffet table and call him Bob. Which of the following explains your mistake?
column5: EPPP-P3-LEA-Memory and Forgetting-14 Answer A is correct. Retroactive interference occurs when more recently acquired information (e.g., "Bob") interferes with the ability to recall previously acquired information (e.g., "Bill").
column8: Retroactive interference occurs when more recently acquired information (e.g., "Bob") interferes with the ability to recall previously acquired information (e.g., "Bill").
column10: Retroactive interference, where more recently acquired information interferes with the ability to recall previously learned information, explains why you called your co-worker's husband "Bob" after earlier meeting him as "Bill".

column3: Which of the following is caused by a chromosomal deletion?
column5: EPPP-P3-LIF-Early Influences on Development - Prenatal Development-03 Answer D is correct. Prader-Willi syndrome is characterized by intellectual disability, short stature, small hands and feet, and obesity. Of the disorders listed, it's the only one that's due to a chromosomal deletion.
column7: Early Influences on Development - Prenatal Development
column8: Prader-Willi syndrome is characterized by intellectual disability, short stature, small hands and feet, and obesity. Of the disorders listed, it's the only one that's due to a chromosomal deletion.
column10: Prader-Willi syndrome, characterized by intellectual disability, short stature, small hands and feet, and obesity, is the only disorder in the list caused by a chromosomal deletion.

column3: The suprachiasmatic nucleus controls the sleep-wake cycle by triggering changes in the release of __________ by the pineal gland.
column5: EPPP-P3-PHY-Brain Regions/Functions - Hindbrain, Midbrain, and Subcortical Forebrain Structures-03 Answer B is correct. The suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN) controls the sleep-wake cycle by receiving information about available light from the eyes and triggering changes in the pineal gland's secretion of melatonin, a hormone that facilitates sleep. During the day, the SCN signals the pineal gland to reduce its secretion of melatonin; during the night, it signals the pineal gland to increase its secretion of melatonin.
column7: Brain Regions/Functions - Hindbrain, Midbrain, and Subcortical Forebrain Structures
column8: The suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN) controls the sleep-wake cycle by receiving information about available light from the eyes and triggering changes in the pineal gland's secretion of melatonin, a hormone that facilitates sleep. During the day, the SCN signals the pineal gland to reduce its secretion of melatonin; during the night, it signals the pineal gland to increase its secretion of melatonin.
column10: The suprachiasmatic nucleus controls the sleep-wake cycle by triggering changes in the release of melatonin by the pineal gland.

column3: Your new clients are married partners who have been arguing more often since their youngest child left home two months ago to attend college. They say that all three of their children are no longer living at home and they don't seem to have much in common any more. As the partners describe their daily lives, you learn they just joined the same church that you belong to. As an ethical psychologist, you should:
column4: D. consider if their church membership is likely to impact your effectiveness as a therapist before deciding what to do.
column5: EPPP-P3-ETH-APA Ethics Code Standards 3 & 4-06 Answer D is correct. Standard 3.05 of the APA Ethics Code prohibits multiple relationships that "could be reasonably expected to impair the psychologist's objectivity, competence, or effectiveness  or otherwise risks exploitation or harm to the person." And Standard III.30 of the Canadian Code of Ethics requires psychologists to "avoid dual relationships  that are not justified by the nature of the activity, by cultural or geographic factors, or where there is a lack of reasonably accessible alternatives." Neither Code prohibits all types of multiple relationships; and, in the situation described in this question, your first action would be to determine if belonging to the same church as your clients constitutes a multiple relationship that's likely to have an adverse impact on therapy.
column8: Standard 3.05 of the APA Ethics Code prohibits multiple relationships that "could be reasonably expected to impair the psychologist's objectivity, competence, or effectiveness  or otherwise risks exploitation or harm to the person." And Standard III.30 of the Canadian Code of Ethics requires psychologists to "avoid dual relationships  that are not justified by the nature of the activity, by cultural or geographic factors, or where there is a lack of reasonably accessible alternatives." Neither Code prohibits all types of multiple relationships; and, in the situation described in this question, your first action would be to determine if belonging to the same church as your clients constitutes a multiple relationship that's likely to have an adverse impact on therapy.
column10: Before deciding how to proceed, an ethical psychologist should consider whether their shared church membership with new clients is likely to impact their effectiveness as a therapist, in accordance with ethical standards prohibiting multiple relationships that could impair objectivity or competence.

column3: A young woman started having __________ seizures when she was a child. She does not lose consciousness during a seizure but experiences motor and sensory symptoms that include jerky movements in her arms and legs, eye blinking, and numbness, tingling, and other abnormal sensations.
column5: EPPP-P3-PHY-Neurological and Endocrine Disorders-19 Answer C is correct. Partial seizures are also known as focal seizures and involve one side of the brain and body (although they can spread to the other side of the brain and become generalized seizures). Simple and complex partial seizures both involve sensory and motor symptoms, but simple partial seizures don't cause a loss of consciousness while complex partial seizures do impair consciousness.
column8: Partial seizures are also known as focal seizures and involve one side of the brain and body (although they can spread to the other side of the brain and become generalized seizures). Simple and complex partial seizures both involve sensory and motor symptoms, but simple partial seizures don't cause a loss of consciousness while complex partial seizures do impair consciousness.
column10: A young woman started having simple partial seizures when she was a child, experiencing motor and sensory symptoms including jerky movements, eye blinking, and abnormal sensations without losing consciousness.

column3: Research on the "jigsaw classroom" (Aronson & Osherow, 1980) found that having students work together in teams to complete an assignment helped reduce intergroup hostility caused by racial and ethnic differences. The results of this research are consistent with studies assessing the effects of which of the following?
column5: EPPP-P3-SOC-Prosocial Behavior and Prejudice/Discrimination-13 Answer A is correct. Consistent with the results of Sherif's (1966) Robbers Cave study, Aronson and Osherow found that introducing superordinate goals reduced intergroup hostility.
column8: Consistent with the results of Sherif's (1966) Robbers Cave study, Aronson and Osherow found that introducing superordinate goals reduced intergroup hostility.
column10: Research on the "jigsaw classroom" found that having students work together in teams to complete an assignment helped reduce intergroup hostility caused by racial and ethnic differences, consistent with studies assessing the effects of superordinate goals.

column3: Development of which of the following was based on the assumption that planning, attention, simultaneous processing, and sequential processing are the essential elements of intellectual functioning?
column5: EPPP-P3-PAS-Other Measures of Cognitive Ability-07 Answer C is correct. The Cognitive Assessment System (CAS) is based on J. P. Das, J. A. Naglieri, and J. R. Kirby's PASS model of intelligence which was derived, in part, from Luria's neuropsychological theory of cognitive abilities. According to the PASS model, planning, attention, simultaneous processing, and sequential processing are the essential components of intelligence (Assessment of cognitive processes: The PASS theory of intelligence, Boston, MA, Allyn & Bacon, 1994).
column8: The Cognitive Assessment System (CAS) is based on J. P. Das, J. A. Naglieri, and J. R. Kirby's PASS model of intelligence which was derived, in part, from Luria's neuropsychological theory of cognitive abilities. According to the PASS model, planning, attention, simultaneous processing, and sequential processing are the essential components of intelligence (Assessment of cognitive processes: The PASS theory of intelligence, Boston, MA, Allyn & Bacon, 1994).
column10: The Cognitive Assessment System was based on the assumption that planning, attention, simultaneous processing, and sequential processing are the essential elements of intellectual functioning.

column3: Dr. Crosby, a licensed psychologist, wants to take two weeks off next month from her full-time private practice to spend time with her father who lives alone and will be having hip replacement surgery. With regard to her current therapy clients, Dr. Crosby's best course of action is to:
column4: B. give her clients the phone number of a colleague who is willing to accept their calls and see them in case of an emergency.
column5: EPPP-P3-ETH-APA Ethics Code Standards 3 & 4-07 Answer B is correct. Standard 3.12 of the APA Ethics Code and Standard II.33 of the Canadian Code of Ethics address the interruption of services in a general way, and it's up to psychologists to determine the best course of action. Since Dr. Crosby's absence is going to be relatively brief, the best action of those described in the answers would be to discuss it with clients immediately and provide them with the phone number of a colleague whom they can contact in case of an emergency. Note that answer A is not the best answer because psychologists may, of course, take time off from work and it's not likely that Dr. Crosby would be able to keep all of her appointments while caring for her father.
column8: Standard 3.12 of the APA Ethics Code and Standard II.33 of the Canadian Code of Ethics address the interruption of services in a general way, and it's up to psychologists to determine the best course of action. Since Dr. Crosby's absence is going to be relatively brief, the best action of those described in the answers would be to discuss it with clients immediately and provide them with the phone number of a colleague whom they can contact in case of an emergency. Note that answer A is not the best answer because psychologists may, of course, take time off from work and it's not likely that Dr. Crosby would be able to keep all of her appointments while caring for her father.
column10: Dr. Crosby, a licensed psychologist, should give her clients the phone number of a colleague who is willing to accept their calls and see them in case of an emergency during her two-week absence from her full-time private practice to spend time with her father having hip replacement surgery.

column3: To determine the correlation between college graduate (yes or no) and yearly income in dollars, you would use which of the following correlation coefficients?
column5: EPPP-P3-RMS-Correlation and Regression-08 Answer C is correct. The point biserial correlation coefficient is used when one variable is a true dichotomy (e.g., college graduate or nongraduate) and the other variable is continuous (e.g. yearly income in dollars).
column8: The point biserial correlation coefficient is used when one variable is a true dichotomy (e.g., college graduate or nongraduate) and the other variable is continuous (e.g. yearly income in dollars).
column10: To determine the correlation between college graduate (yes or no) and yearly income in dollars, a point biserial correlation coefficient would be used.

column3: A person taking which of the following drugs should avoid eating foods containing tyramine?
column5: EPPP-P3-PHY-Psychopharmacology - Antipsychotics and Antidepressants-22 Answer B is correct. Ingesting foods containing tyramine (e.g., aged cheese and processed meat) while taking an MAOI can cause a life-threatening hypertensive crisis. Consequently, these foods must be avoided.
column8: Ingesting foods containing tyramine (e.g., aged cheese and processed meat) while taking an MAOI can cause a life-threatening hypertensive crisis. Consequently, these foods must be avoided.
column10: A person taking monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs) should avoid eating foods containing tyramine.

column3: A practitioner of narrative family therapy will focus on:
column4: D. how the presenting problem has affected the family.
column5: EPPP-P3-CLI-Family Therapies and Group Therapies-14 Answer D is correct. Narrative family therapy is based on the assumption that the presenting problem is the problem. Consequently, therapy involves obtaining a description of the problem from family members, separating the family from the problem by externalizing it, and determining how the problem has affected family members.
column8: Narrative family therapy is based on the assumption that the presenting problem is the problem. Consequently, therapy involves obtaining a description of the problem from family members, separating the family from the problem by externalizing it, and determining how the problem has affected family members.
column10: A practitioner of narrative family therapy will focus on how the presenting problem has affected the family.

column3: Tannenbaum's (2015) meta-analysis of research on the use of fear to change people's attitudes and behaviors found that:
column4: D. fear arousal is most effective when it describes what action to take to avoid the negative consequences associated with a behavior.
column5: EPPP-P3-SOC-Persuasion-07 Answer D is correct. Tannenbaum et al.'s (2015) meta-analysis found that persuasive messages that arouse a relatively high level of fear are most effective when certain conditions are met - e.g., when they describe the negative consequences of the behavior and recommend actions that will help reduce or eliminate those consequences.
column8: Tannenbaum et al.'s (2015) meta-analysis found that persuasive messages that arouse a relatively high level of fear are most effective when certain conditions are met - e.g., when they describe the negative consequences of the behavior and recommend actions that will help reduce or eliminate those consequences.
column10: Tannenbaum's meta-analysis found that fear arousal is most effective when it describes what action to take to avoid the negative consequences associated with a behavior.

column3: Of the core characteristics of the Type A behavior pattern, ________ has been most closely linked to an increased risk for heart disease and other health problems.
column5: EPPP-P3-ORG-Satisfaction, Commitment, and Stress-25 Answer A is correct. As described by Friedman and Rosenman (1959), the Type A behavior pattern is characterized by a chronic sense of time urgency, excessive competitiveness, and hostility. Of these, hostility is most associated with an increased risk for heart disease and other health problems.
column8: As described by Friedman and Rosenman (1959), the Type A behavior pattern is characterized by a chronic sense of time urgency, excessive competitiveness, and hostility. Of these, hostility is most associated with an increased risk for heart disease and other health problems.
column10: Of the core characteristics of the Type A behavior pattern, hostility has been most closely linked to an increased risk for heart disease and other health problems.

column3: Use of which of the following drugs is most likely to cause pupillary constriction?
column5: EPPP-P3-PPA-Substance-Related and Addictive Disorders--04 Answer C is correct. Pupillary constriction (pinpoint pupils) is a characteristic symptom of opioid and barbiturate use. In contrast, pupillary dilation is associated with the drugs listed in answers A, B, and D.
column8: Pupillary constriction (pinpoint pupils) is a characteristic symptom of opioid and barbiturate use. In contrast, pupillary dilation is associated with the drugs listed in answers A, B, and D.
column10: Use of opioids is most likely to cause pupillary constriction.

column3: ____________ refers to the tendency of a group to make more extreme decisions than would be made by individual group members working alone.
column5: EPPP-P3-ORG-Organizational Decision-Making-20 Answer B is correct. Group polarization is the tendency for an entire group to make more risky or more cautious decisions than individual group members would make alone.
column8: Group polarization is the tendency for an entire group to make more risky or more cautious decisions than individual group members would make alone.
column10: Group polarization refers to the tendency of a group to make more extreme decisions than would be made by individual group members working alone.

column3: The Stroop Color Word Test is a measure of:
column5: EPPP-P3-PAS-Clinical Tests-09 Answer B is correct. The Stroop Color Word Test measures selective (focused) attention and the abilities to concentrate and inhibit the most prepotent response.
column8: The Stroop Color Word Test measures selective (focused) attention and the abilities to concentrate and inhibit the most prepotent response.
column10: The Stroop Color Word Test measures selective (focused) attention and the abilities to concentrate and inhibit the most prepotent response.

column3: Piaget found that some forms of conservation are understood before others and that the forms of conservation develop in a predictable sequence. He referred to this as:
column5: EPPP-P3-LIF-Cognitive Development-12 Answer C is correct. Piaget used the term horizontal decalage to describe the gradual acquisition of abilities within a stage (e.g., the gradual development of conservation skills within the concrete operational stage).
column8: Piaget used the term horizontal decalage to describe the gradual acquisition of abilities within a stage (e.g., the gradual development of conservation skills within the concrete operational stage).
column10: Piaget used the term horizontal decalage to describe the gradual acquisition of abilities within a stage (e.g., the gradual development of conservation skills within the concrete operational stage).

column3: An interviewee would be classified as ________ using the Adult Attachment Interview (AAI) when she describes early relationships with her parents in very positive terms but is unable to give examples that support her evaluation.
column5: EPPP-P3-LIF-Socioemotional Development - Attachment, Emotions, and Social Relationships-19 Answer B is correct. The AAI is used to assess an adult's early attachment experiences and classifies interviewees as autonomous, dismissing, or preoccupied. Individuals are classified as dismissing when they provide positive descriptions of their early relationships with their parents, but their descriptions are not supported or are contradicted by their actual memories.
column7: Socioemotional Development - Attachment, Emotions, and Social Relationships
column8: The AAI is used to assess an adult's early attachment experiences and classifies interviewees as autonomous, dismissing, or preoccupied. Individuals are classified as dismissing when they provide positive descriptions of their early relationships with their parents, but their descriptions are not supported or are contradicted by their actual memories.
column10: The Adult Attachment Interview classifies interviewees as dismissing when they provide positive descriptions of their early relationships with their parents, but their descriptions are not supported or are contradicted by their actual memories.

column3: Which of the following best describes the requirements of the ethics codes of the American and Canadian Psychological Associations regarding sexual relationships with supervisees?
column4: A. Sexual relationships with supervisees over whom psychologists have evaluative authority are prohibited.
column5: EPPP-P3-ETH-APA Ethics Code Standards 7 & 8-17 Answer A is correct. Sexual relationships with supervisees are addressed in Standard 7.07 of the APA Ethics Code and Standard II.29 of the Canadian Code of Ethics, which both prohibit sexual intimacies with supervisees over whom psychologists have evaluative authority.
column8: Sexual relationships with supervisees are addressed in Standard 7.07 of the APA Ethics Code and Standard II.29 of the Canadian Code of Ethics, which both prohibit sexual intimacies with supervisees over whom psychologists have evaluative authority.
column10: Sexual relationships with supervisees over whom psychologists have evaluative authority are prohibited according to the ethics codes of the American and Canadian Psychological Associations.

column3: A practitioner of which of the following types of therapy would most likely agree that a goal of therapy is to replace "dirty discomfort" with "clean discomfort"?
column5: EPPP-P3-CLI-Cognitive-Behavioral Therapies-18 Answer A is correct. Practitioners of acceptance and commitment therapy distinguish between clean and dirty discomfort. Clean discomfort is unpleasant or painful but is a normal and inevitable part of daily life, while dirty discomfort occurs when a person tries to control clean discomfort, which has the effect of intensifying the discomfort. A goal of therapy is to replace dirty discomfort with clean discomfort.
column8: Practitioners of acceptance and commitment therapy distinguish between clean and dirty discomfort. Clean discomfort is unpleasant or painful but is a normal and inevitable part of daily life, while dirty discomfort occurs when a person tries to control clean discomfort, which has the effect of intensifying the discomfort. A goal of therapy is to replace dirty discomfort with clean discomfort.
column10: Practitioners of acceptance and commitment therapy distinguish between clean and dirty discomfort, with a goal of therapy being to replace dirty discomfort with clean discomfort.

column3: A practitioner of reality therapy would agree that psychopathology is the result of:
column4: A. adoption of a failure identity.
column5: EPPP-P3-CLI-Psychodynamic and Humanistic Therapies-05 Answer A is correct. According to reality therapists, when a person chooses to fulfill his/her needs in irresponsible ways, the person has adopted a failure identity which, in turn, causes depression and other problems.
column8: According to reality therapists, when a person chooses to fulfill his/her needs in irresponsible ways, the person has adopted a failure identity which, in turn, causes depression and other problems.
column10: According to reality therapists, when a person chooses to fulfill his/her needs in irresponsible ways, the person has adopted a failure identity which, in turn, causes depression and other problems.

column3: A person with bilateral damage to the __________ will have trouble recognizing fear in human facial expressions.
column5: EPPP-P3-PHY-Brain Regions/Functions - Hindbrain, Midbrain, and Subcortical Forebrain Structures-01 Answer C is correct. People with bilateral damage to the amygdala often have difficulty recognizing negative emotions in facial expressions, especially fear. See, e.g., R. Adolphs et al., A mechanism for impaired fear recognition after amygdala damage, Nature, 433(7021), 68-72, 2005.
column7: Brain Regions/Functions - Hindbrain, Midbrain, and Subcortical Forebrain Structures
column8: People with bilateral damage to the amygdala often have difficulty recognizing negative emotions in facial expressions, especially fear. See, e.g., R. Adolphs et al., A mechanism for impaired fear recognition after amygdala damage, Nature, 433(7021), 68-72, 2005.
column10: People with bilateral damage to the amygdala often have difficulty recognizing negative emotions in facial expressions, especially fear.

column3: The beta-blockers propranolol (Inderal) and atenolol (Tenormin) are:
column4: B. more useful for reducing the physical symptoms of anxiety than its emotional or cognitive symptoms.
column5: EPPP-P3-PHY-Psychopharmacology - Other Psychoactive Drugs-25 Answer B is correct. Although propranolol and atenolol have been found useful for relieving the physical symptoms of some types of anxiety (especially performance-related anxiety), they do not have a direct effect on its emotional or cognitive symptoms.
column8: Although propranolol and atenolol have been found useful for relieving the physical symptoms of some types of anxiety (especially performance-related anxiety), they do not have a direct effect on its emotional or cognitive symptoms.
column10: Propranolol and atenolol have been found useful for relieving the physical symptoms of some types of anxiety (especially performance-related anxiety), but they do not have a direct effect on its emotional or cognitive symptoms.

column3: As described by Aaron Beck, ________ are triggered by an event or stimulus and elicit emotional and behavioral responses.
column5: EPPP-P3-CLI-Cognitive-Behavioral Therapies-15 Answer A is correct. Automatic thoughts are spontaneous thoughts that "intercede between an event or stimulus and the individual's emotional and behavioral reactions" (A. T. Beck and M. E. Weishaar, Cognitive therapy, in A. Freeman, K. M. Simon, L. E. Beutler, and H. Arkowitz (Eds.), Comprehensive handbook of cognitive therapy, New York, Plenum, 1989, p. 254).
column8: Automatic thoughts are spontaneous thoughts that "intercede between an event or stimulus and the individual's emotional and behavioral reactions" (A. T. Beck and M. E. Weishaar, Cognitive therapy, in A. Freeman, K. M. Simon, L. E. Beutler, and H. Arkowitz (Eds.), Comprehensive handbook of cognitive therapy, New York, Plenum, 1989, p. 254).
column10: Automatic thoughts are spontaneous thoughts that "intercede between an event or stimulus and the individual's emotional and behavioral reactions".

column3: Dr. Watson, a newly licensed psychologist, is having trouble determining the appropriate diagnosis for a new client and decides to consult with a more experienced colleague. To be consistent with ethical requirements, Dr. Watson:
column4: D. does not have to obtain the client's authorization as long as he's able to disguise the client's identity while consulting with the colleague.
column5: EPPP-P3-ETH-APA Ethics Code Standards 3 & 4-10 Answer D is correct. This answer is most consistent with Standard 4.06 of the APA Ethics Code. It states that, when consulting with a colleague about a client, psychologists do not disclose confidential information "that reasonably could lead to the identification of a client/patient  unless they have obtained the prior consent of the person." It's also consistent with Standard I.45 of the Canadian Code of Ethics, which states that psychologists "share confidential information with others only to the extent reasonably needed for the purpose of sharing, and only with the informed consent of those involved, or in a manner that the individuals and groups  involved cannot be identified."
column8: This answer is most consistent with Standard 4.06 of the APA Ethics Code. It states that, when consulting with a colleague about a client, psychologists do not disclose confidential information "that reasonably could lead to the identification of a client/patient  unless they have obtained the prior consent of the person." It's also consistent with Standard I.45 of the Canadian Code of Ethics, which states that psychologists "share confidential information with others only to the extent reasonably needed for the purpose of sharing, and only with the informed consent of those involved, or in a manner that the individuals and groups  involved cannot be identified."
column10: Dr. Watson, a newly licensed psychologist, is allowed to consult with a more experienced colleague about a new client without obtaining the client's authorization as long as he can disguise the client's identity, which is consistent with the APA Ethics Code and the Canadian Code of Ethics.

column3: All of the single-subject designs share which of the following characteristics?
column4: C. The dependent variable is measured multiple times during each phase.
column5: EPPP-P3-RMS-Research - Internal/External Validity-05 Answer C is correct. All of the single-subject designs involve measuring the dependent variable multiple times at regular intervals during each baseline phase and each treatment phase. The other answers apply to some, but not all, of the single-subject designs.
column8: All of the single-subject designs involve measuring the dependent variable multiple times at regular intervals during each baseline phase and each treatment phase. The other answers apply to some, but not all, of the single-subject designs.
column10: All single-subject designs involve measuring the dependent variable multiple times at regular intervals during each baseline phase and each treatment phase.

column3: Which of the following are evidence-based treatments for postpartum depression?
column4: A. cognitive-behavioral therapy and interpersonal psychotherapy
column5: EPPP-P3-PPA-Bipolar and Depressive Disorders--18 Answer A is correct. Cognitive-behavioral therapy and interpersonal psychotherapy are evidence-based treatments for postpartum depression, especially postpartum depression with mild to moderate symptoms. Physical exercise and repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation have been found to have beneficial effects for this disorder, but they are not considered to be evidence-based treatments.
column8: Cognitive-behavioral therapy and interpersonal psychotherapy are evidence-based treatments for postpartum depression, especially postpartum depression with mild to moderate symptoms. Physical exercise and repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation have been found to have beneficial effects for this disorder, but they are not considered to be evidence-based treatments.
column10: Cognitive-behavioral therapy and interpersonal psychotherapy are evidence-based treatments for postpartum depression, especially postpartum depression with mild to moderate symptoms.

column3: With regard to systems theory, positive feedback is:
column5: EPPP-P4-CLI-Family Therapies and Group Therapies-10 Answer C is correct. Positive feedback amplifies deviation from the status quo and promotes change, while negative feedback counteracts (attenuates) deviation and maintains the status quo.
column8: Positive feedback amplifies deviation from the status quo and promotes change, while negative feedback counteracts (attenuates) deviation and maintains the status quo.

column3: Which of the following best describes ethical guidelines for requiring students to disclose personal information in course- or program-related activities about any psychological treatment they've received in the past?
column4: D. Requiring students to do so is acceptable when doing so is clearly identified as a requirement in program and admissions materials.
column5: EPPP-P4-ETH-APA Ethics Code Standards 7 & 8-19 Answer D is correct. This issue is addressed in Standard 7.04 of the APA's Ethics Code and the Values Statement for Standard I and Standard I.8 of the Canadian Code of Ethics. Standard 7.04 states that students should not be required to disclose personal information in course- or program-related activities related to psychological treatment except in two circumstances: (a) this requirement has been clearly identified in program and admissions materials or (b) the information is needed to "evaluate or obtain assistance for students whose personal problems could reasonably be judged to be preventing them from performing their training- or professionally related activities in a competent manner or posing a threat to the student or others."
column8: This issue is addressed in Standard 7.04 of the APA's Ethics Code and the Values Statement for Standard I and Standard I.8 of the Canadian Code of Ethics. Standard 7.04 states that students should not be required to disclose personal information in course- or program-related activities related to psychological treatment except in two circumstances: (a) this requirement has been clearly identified in program and admissions materials or (b) the information is needed to "evaluate or obtain assistance for students whose personal problems could reasonably be judged to be preventing them from performing their training- or professionally related activities in a competent manner or posing a threat to the student or others."
column10: Error: Rewrite failed

column3: Of the antipsychotic drugs, __________ is most likely to be a side effect of clozapine.
column5: EPPP-P4-PHY-Psychopharmacology - Antipsychotics and Antidepressants-24 Answer D is correct. Of the antipsychotics, the atypical drug clozapine is most likely to produce agranulocytosis, which is a rare but potentially fatal blood disorder that's characterized by an abnormally low level of white blood cells. Consequently, regular blood monitoring is required for people taking this drug. An advantage of clozapine is that it is less likely than many other antipsychotics to produce the side effects listed in answers A, B, and C. See, e.g., L.A. Labbate, J. F. Rosenbaum, M. Fava, and G. W. Arana, Handbook of psychiatric drug therapy, Philadelphia, Lippincott Williams & Wilkins, 2010.
column8: Of the antipsychotics, the atypical drug clozapine is most likely to produce agranulocytosis, which is a rare but potentially fatal blood disorder that's characterized by an abnormally low level of white blood cells. Consequently, regular blood monitoring is required for people taking this drug. An advantage of clozapine is that it is less likely than many other antipsychotics to produce the side effects listed in answers A, B, and C. See, e.g., L.A. Labbate, J. F. Rosenbaum, M. Fava, and G. W. Arana, Handbook of psychiatric drug therapy, Philadelphia, Lippincott Williams & Wilkins, 2010.
column10: Of the antipsychotics, the atypical drug clozapine is most likely to produce agranulocytosis, a rare but potentially fatal blood disorder characterized by an abnormally low level of white blood cells, requiring regular blood monitoring.

column3: When prison inmates and their counselors were asked to explain why the prisoners committed their offenses, most inmates cited situational factors while the counselors cited dispositional factors. This provides support for which of the following?
column5: EPPP-P4-SOC-Social Cognition - Causal Attributions-01 Answer D is correct. This question describes a study conducted by K. Saulnier and D. Perlman (The actor-observer bias is alive and well in prison: A sequel to Wells, Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin, 7, 559-564, 1981). The results of their study provided support for the actor-observer effect, which predicts that actors tend to attribute their own behaviors to situational factors while observers tend to attribute them to dispositional factors.
column8: This question describes a study conducted by K. Saulnier and D. Perlman (The actor-observer bias is alive and well in prison: A sequel to Wells, Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin, 7, 559-564, 1981). The results of their study provided support for the actor-observer effect, which predicts that actors tend to attribute their own behaviors to situational factors while observers tend to attribute them to dispositional factors.
column10: This study provided support for the actor-observer effect, which predicts that actors tend to attribute their own behaviors to situational factors while observers tend to attribute them to dispositional factors.

column3: As described by Helms (1993), a person in the __________ stage of White identity development is oblivious to racial/cultural issues and has a race- or culture-neutral perspective.
column5: EPPP-P4-CLI-Cross-Cultural Issues - Identity Development Models-27 Answer D is correct. Helms's White racial identity development model distinguishes between six stages (statuses). In order, these are contact, disintegration, reintegration, pseudo-independence, immersion-emersion, and autonomy. According to this model, people in the initial contact stage have little awareness of racial or cultural issues.
column8: Helms's White racial identity development model distinguishes between six stages (statuses). In order, these are contact, disintegration, reintegration, pseudo-independence, immersion-emersion, and autonomy. According to this model, people in the initial contact stage have little awareness of racial or cultural issues.
column10: According to Helms's White racial identity development model, people in the initial contact stage have little awareness of racial or cultural issues.

column3: The items selected for inclusion in the __________ assess 15 manifest needs that were identified by Henry Murray.
column5: EPPP-P4-PAS-Other Measures of Personality-02 Answer D is correct. The items included in the EPPS (Edwards Personal Preference Schedule) assess the 15 needs identified in Murray's theory of needs (e.g., achievement, autonomy, affiliation, dominance).
column8: The items included in the EPPS (Edwards Personal Preference Schedule) assess the 15 needs identified in Murray's theory of needs (e.g., achievement, autonomy, affiliation, dominance).
column10: The items included in the EPPS (Edwards Personal Preference Schedule) assess the 15 needs identified in Murray's theory of needs (e.g., achievement, autonomy, affiliation, dominance).

column3: Dr. Sholen has trained a psychology intern to administer and score several psychological tests that she frequently administers to clients who have been referred to her for psychological assessment. Dr. Sholen always interprets the clients' scores and, when preparing the psychological reports for clients who have taken these tests, she doesn't indicate that they were administered and scored by the intern. This practice is:
column4: D. unethical since the intern should be identified as the person who administered and scored the tests.
column5: EPPP-P4-ETH-APA Ethics Code Standards 3 & 4-11 Answer D is correct. This situation is addressed in Standard 5.01(b) of the APA's Ethics Code and Standards III.1, III.5, and III.22 of the Canadian Code of Ethics. The intern may, in fact, be qualified to administer and score the tests (answer C). However, not indicating that the intern did so in the psychological reports violates the prohibition against providing inaccurate or deceptive statements about a psychologist's professional services.
column8: This situation is addressed in Standard 5.01(b) of the APA's Ethics Code and Standards III.1, III.5, and III.22 of the Canadian Code of Ethics. The intern may, in fact, be qualified to administer and score the tests (answer C). However, not indicating that the intern did so in the psychological reports violates the prohibition against providing inaccurate or deceptive statements about a psychologist's professional services.
column10: This practice is unethical since the intern should be identified as the person who administered and scored the tests.

column3: The standard error of measurement is used to:
column4: C. construct a confidence interval around an examinee's obtained score.
column5: EPPP-P4-TES-Item Analysis and Test Reliability-04 Answer C is correct. The standard error of measurement is used to construct a confidence interval around an obtained score and indicates the range within which an examinee's true score is likely to fall given his/her obtained score. The standard error of estimate is used to construct a confidence interval around a predicted score (answer D) - i.e., a criterion score that's predicted from an obtained predictor score.
column8: The standard error of measurement is used to construct a confidence interval around an obtained score and indicates the range within which an examinee's true score is likely to fall given his/her obtained score. The standard error of estimate is used to construct a confidence interval around a predicted score (answer D) - i.e., a criterion score that's predicted from an obtained predictor score.
column10: The standard error of measurement is used to construct a confidence interval around an obtained score and indicates the range within which an examinee's true score is likely to fall given his/her obtained score.

column3: Dr. Devlin terminates the internship of one of her interns when she receives a complaint about him from one of his current clients. With regard to ethical requirements, this is acceptable as long as:
column4: C. the client's complaint is valid and Dr. Devlin has previously provided the intern with feedback about his performance.
column5: EPPP-P4-ETH-APA Ethics Code Standards 7 & 8-18 Answer C is correct. This answer is most consistent with the provisions of Standard 7.06(a) of the APA's Ethics Code and Standard II.26 of the Canadian Code of Ethics, which require psychologists to provide supervisees with timely feedback. Although neither Code directly addresses termination of interns, doing so without having provided them with feedback and opportunities to correct undesirable behaviors would violate these standards and the "spirit" of the Codes.
column8: This answer is most consistent with the provisions of Standard 7.06(a) of the APA's Ethics Code and Standard II.26 of the Canadian Code of Ethics, which require psychologists to provide supervisees with timely feedback. Although neither Code directly addresses termination of interns, doing so without having provided them with feedback and opportunities to correct undesirable behaviors would violate these standards and the "spirit" of the Codes.
column10: This is acceptable as long as the client's complaint is valid and Dr. Devlin has previously provided the intern with feedback about his performance.

column3: At an APA convention, you run into a colleague who worked at the mental health clinic where you work until she quit a few months ago. She tells you she's now providing therapy over the Internet and gives you her business card. Several weeks later, you find her card in your wallet and decide to take a look at her website. When you do, you notice that the site seems to provide some inaccurate information about her professional experience. You should:
column4: C. contact the psychologist to discuss her possible violation of ethical requirements.
column5: EPPP-P4-ETH-APA Ethics Code Overview and Standards 1 & 2-01 Answer C is correct. This situation is addressed in Standards 1.04 and 1.05 of the APA's Ethics Code and Standards II.43 and II.44 of the Canadian Code of Ethics. Standards 1.04 and 1.05 require psychologists to attempt to resolve the ethical violations of another psychologist either informally by bringing the behavior to the psychologist's attention or formally by filing a report against the psychologist with an ethics committee or licensing board. Given that the website only "seems to provide" inaccurate information, an attempt at an informal resolution would be the best initial course of action.
column7: APA Ethics Code Overview and Standards 1 & 2
column8: This situation is addressed in Standards 1.04 and 1.05 of the APA's Ethics Code and Standards II.43 and II.44 of the Canadian Code of Ethics. Standards 1.04 and 1.05 require psychologists to attempt to resolve the ethical violations of another psychologist either informally by bringing the behavior to the psychologist's attention or formally by filing a report against the psychologist with an ethics committee or licensing board. Given that the website only "seems to provide" inaccurate information, an attempt at an informal resolution would be the best initial course of action.
column10: This situation is addressed in Standards 1.04 and 1.05 of the APA's Ethics Code and Standards II.43 and II.44 of the Canadian Code of Ethics, and an attempt at an informal resolution would be the best initial course of action.

column3: The "gold standard" treatment for preschool-aged children with ADHD is:
column4: A. parent training in behavior management.
column5: EPPP-P4-PPA-Neurodevelopmental Disorders-38 Answer A is correct. Evidence-based parent-training in behavior management (PTBM) is considered the first-line treatment for preschool children 4 and 5 years of age. It involves teaching parents to reward children's positive behaviors and ignore or redirect their negative behaviors. Included in this category are positive parenting program (triple P), parent-child interaction therapy, and incredible years. Pharmacotherapy (answer D) is not recommended for preschool children unless PTBM has not produced a significant change in behavior.
column8: Evidence-based parent-training in behavior management (PTBM) is considered the first-line treatment for preschool children 4 and 5 years of age. It involves teaching parents to reward children's positive behaviors and ignore or redirect their negative behaviors. Included in this category are positive parenting program (triple P), parent-child interaction therapy, and incredible years. Pharmacotherapy (answer D) is not recommended for preschool children unless PTBM has not produced a significant change in behavior.
column10: Evidence-based parent-training in behavior management (PTBM) is considered the first-line treatment for preschool children 4 and 5 years of age with ADHD.

column3: The time-series group design is most similar to which of the following single-subject designs?
column5: EPPP-P4-RMS-Research - Single-Subject and Group Designs-05 Answer A is correct. The time-series design is a type of within-subjects design that's essentially a group version of the single-subject AB design. It involves measuring the dependent variable at regular intervals multiple times before and after the independent variable is administered.
column8: The time-series design is a type of within-subjects design that's essentially a group version of the single-subject AB design. It involves measuring the dependent variable at regular intervals multiple times before and after the independent variable is administered.
column10: The time-series design is a type of within-subjects design that's essentially a group version of the single-subject AB design.

column3: Piaget's stage theory of cognitive development views development as being:
column5: EPPP-P4-LIF-Cognitive Development-181 Answer B is correct. Piaget's theory proposes discontinuous stages of cognitive development that are characterized by qualitatively different cognitive processes. His theory also proposes that development is an active process in which children interact with the world to construct their own knowledge.
column8: Piaget's theory proposes discontinuous stages of cognitive development that are characterized by qualitatively different cognitive processes. His theory also proposes that development is an active process in which children interact with the world to construct their own knowledge.
column10: Piaget's stage theory of cognitive development views development as being discontinuous and active.

column3: Adele Alvarez, age 23, is brought to therapy by her mother who says that Adele "has always been a little different." Adele says that she sometimes feels like she's detached from her body and is watching "what's going on from some other reality." She also tells you that, for as long as she can remember, she's been "able to read people's minds" and that she thinks that people try to avoid her because of this ability. Adele tells you that she doesn't have any close friends and feels "kind of nervous" when she's around other people. During the entire session, Adele's mood is neutral. Of the following, the most likely diagnosis for Adele is:
column5: EPPP-P4-PPA-Personality Disorders-29 Answer B is correct. Adele's odd beliefs and magical thinking (e.g., her belief that she can read people's minds), suspiciousness (belief that people try to avoid her), lack of close friends, social anxiety, and constricted affect are characteristic of schizotypal personality disorder.
column8: Adele's odd beliefs and magical thinking (e.g., her belief that she can read people's minds), suspiciousness (belief that people try to avoid her), lack of close friends, social anxiety, and constricted affect are characteristic of schizotypal personality disorder.
column10: Adele's odd beliefs and magical thinking, suspiciousness, lack of close friends, social anxiety, and constricted affect are characteristic of schizotypal personality disorder.

column3: Research investigating the effectiveness of mindfulness-based therapy (MBT) has generally found that it is:
column4: A. more effective for treating psychological disorders than physical/medical conditions.
column5: EPPP-P4-CLI-Cognitive-Behavioral Therapies-19 Answer A is correct. MBT includes mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) and mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (MBCT). Based on their meta-analysis of research on MBT, B. Khoury and his colleagues conclude that MBT is effective for treating both psychological disorders and physical/medical conditions but is more effective for psychological disorders, especially depression, anxiety, and stress (Mindfulness-based therapy: A comprehensive meta-analysis, Clinical Psychology Review, 33, 763-771, 2013).
column8: MBT includes mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) and mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (MBCT). Based on their meta-analysis of research on MBT, B. Khoury and his colleagues conclude that MBT is effective for treating both psychological disorders and physical/medical conditions but is more effective for psychological disorders, especially depression, anxiety, and stress (Mindfulness-based therapy: A comprehensive meta-analysis, Clinical Psychology Review, 33, 763-771, 2013).
column10: Mindfulness-based therapy is more effective for treating psychological disorders than physical/medical conditions.

column3: After her sixth therapy session with Rusty R., Dr. Berstein realizes that she's attracted to him and that, between sessions, she sometimes thinks about what it would be like to spend time with him outside of therapy. As an ethical psychologist, Dr. Berstein should:
column4: B. obtain professional consultation to determine the best course of action.
column5: EPPP-P4-ETH-APA Ethics Code Overview and Standards 1 & 2-03 Answer B is correct. This answer is most consistent with Standard 2.06(b) of the APA's Ethics Code and Standard II.11 of the Canadian Code of Ethics. Standard 2.06(b) states that, "when psychologists become aware of personal problems that may interfere with their performing work-related duties adequately, they take appropriate measures, such as obtaining professional consultation or assistance, and determine whether they should limit, suspend, or terminate their work-related duties."
column7: APA Ethics Code Overview and Standards 1 & 2
column8: This answer is most consistent with Standard 2.06(b) of the APA's Ethics Code and Standard II.11 of the Canadian Code of Ethics. Standard 2.06(b) states that, "when psychologists become aware of personal problems that may interfere with their performing work-related duties adequately, they take appropriate measures, such as obtaining professional consultation or assistance, and determine whether they should limit, suspend, or terminate their work-related duties."
column10: As an ethical psychologist, Dr. Berstein should obtain professional consultation to determine the best course of action regarding her attraction to her client Rusty R.

column3: The effectiveness of multisystemic therapy (MST) for adolescents with severe conduct problems has been evaluated by a number of studies. Which of the following is the best conclusion about the outcomes of these studies?
column4: C. MST is about equally effective for African American youth and European youth.
column5: EPPP-P4-PPA-Disruptive, Impulse-Control, and Conduct Disorders--19 Answer C is correct. An advantage of MST is that many of the studies evaluating its effectiveness have included African American and other racial/ethnic minority families and families at different levels of socioeconomic status. These studies have found that the benefits of MST are not affected by race or ethnicity or socioeconomic status (e.g., Henggeler & Sheidow, 2012). Outcome similarities for families of different racial/ethnic groups and socioeconomic status have been attributed to the fact that MST procedures can be adjusted to the characteristics of each family.
column8: An advantage of MST is that many of the studies evaluating its effectiveness have included African American and other racial/ethnic minority families and families at different levels of socioeconomic status. These studies have found that the benefits of MST are not affected by race or ethnicity or socioeconomic status (e.g., Henggeler & Sheidow, 2012). Outcome similarities for families of different racial/ethnic groups and socioeconomic status have been attributed to the fact that MST procedures can be adjusted to the characteristics of each family.
column10: Multisystemic therapy is about equally effective for African American youth and European youth.

column3: Which of the following neuroimaging techniques is used to study abnormalities in the brain's white matter?
column5: EPPP-P4-PHY-Neurological and Endocrine Disorders-63 Answer D is correct. Diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) is a special application of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) that is used to detect abnormalities in the brain's white matter, which consists of myelinated axons that connect different areas of the brain. It does this by identifying the rate and direction of the movement of water molecules along the axons.
column8: Diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) is a special application of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) that is used to detect abnormalities in the brain's white matter, which consists of myelinated axons that connect different areas of the brain. It does this by identifying the rate and direction of the movement of water molecules along the axons.
column10: Diffusion tensor imaging is used to study abnormalities in the brain's white matter.

column3: Children usually pass the mirror self-recognition test by _____ months of age, but an exception is children with Down syndrome who usually do not pass the test until they are _____ months of age.
column5: EPPP-P4-LIF-Socioemotional Development: Temperament and Personality-177 Answer C is correct. By 18 to 24 months of age, most children pass the mirror self-recognition test. However, children with Down syndrome usually do not pass the test until they are 36 to 48 months of age when their cognitive developmental age is equivalent to the level of younger children who do not have cognitive developmental delays.
column8: By 18 to 24 months of age, most children pass the mirror self-recognition test. However, children with Down syndrome usually do not pass the test until they are 36 to 48 months of age when their cognitive developmental age is equivalent to the level of younger children who do not have cognitive developmental delays.
column10: Most children pass the mirror self-recognition test by 18 to 24 months of age, but children with Down syndrome usually do not pass the test until they are 36 to 48 months of age.

column3: A unique feature of multisystemic therapy (MST) is its emphasis on quality assurance and improvement that was based on the results of research confirming that its effectiveness depends on a high level of:
column5: EPPP-P4-CLI-Family and Group Therapies-109 Answer C is correct. Treatment fidelity refers to the degree to which a treatment is delivered as intended, and research has demonstrated that positive clinical outcomes of MST depend on a high level of treatment fidelity. The results of this research led to the development of a quality assurance and improvement program for MST that promotes fidelity.
column8: Treatment fidelity refers to the degree to which a treatment is delivered as intended, and research has demonstrated that positive clinical outcomes of MST depend on a high level of treatment fidelity. The results of this research led to the development of a quality assurance and improvement program for MST that promotes fidelity.
column10: The effectiveness of multisystemic therapy depends on a high level of treatment fidelity.

column3: For practitioners of interpersonal therapy (IPT), depression is:
column5: EPPP-P4-CLI-Brief Therapies-07 Answer D is correct. As described by J. C. Markowitz and M. M. Weissman, IPT is based on the assumption that "depression is a medical illness, rather than the patient's fault or personal defect; moreover, it is a treatable condition" [Interpersonal psychotherapy: Principles and applications, World Psychiatry, 3(3), 136-139, 2004].
column8: As described by J. C. Markowitz and M. M. Weissman, IPT is based on the assumption that "depression is a medical illness, rather than the patient's fault or personal defect; moreover, it is a treatable condition" [Interpersonal psychotherapy: Principles and applications, World Psychiatry, 3(3), 136-139, 2004].
column10: Interpersonal therapy views depression as a medically based condition.

column3: The 80% (four-fifths) rule is used to:
column4: D. determine if a selection test is having an adverse impact.
column5: EPPP-P4-ORG-Employee Selection - Evaluation of Techniques-09 Answer D is correct. The Uniform Guidelines on Employee Selection Procedures describes the 80% rule (also known as the four-fifths rule) as a method for determining if a selection test or other employment procedure is having an adverse impact.
column8: The Uniform Guidelines on Employee Selection Procedures describes the 80% rule (also known as the four-fifths rule) as a method for determining if a selection test or other employment procedure is having an adverse impact.
column10: The 80% (four-fifths) rule is used to determine if a selection test is having an adverse impact.

column3: Which of the following neurotransmitters in the mesolimbic pathway is known to be an important contributor to the rewarding effects of cocaine, amphetamines, and other addictive drugs?
column5: EPPP-P4-PHY-Nervous System, Neurons, and Neurotransmitters-12 Answer D is correct. Dopamine is the neurotransmitter that regulates activity in the mesolimbic pathway, which is also known as the brain's reward pathway. Elevated activity in this pathway is responsible for the reinforcing (addictive) effects of cocaine, heroin, and other drugs of abuse that increase dopamine levels.
column8: Dopamine is the neurotransmitter that regulates activity in the mesolimbic pathway, which is also known as the brain's reward pathway. Elevated activity in this pathway is responsible for the reinforcing (addictive) effects of cocaine, heroin, and other drugs of abuse that increase dopamine levels.
column10: Dopamine is the neurotransmitter that regulates activity in the mesolimbic pathway and is known to be an important contributor to the rewarding effects of cocaine, amphetamines, and other addictive drugs.

column3: Withdrawal from which of the following after heavy and prolonged use is most likely to cause seizures?
column5: EPPP-P4-PPA-Substance-Related and Addictive Disorders-26 Answer B is correct. The DSM-5 identifies seizures as a symptom of alcohol withdrawal (and sedative, hypnotic, or anxiolytic withdrawal) but not withdrawal from cannabis, opioids, or stimulants.
column8: The DSM-5 identifies seizures as a symptom of alcohol withdrawal (and sedative, hypnotic, or anxiolytic withdrawal) but not withdrawal from cannabis, opioids, or stimulants.
column10: Withdrawal from alcohol after heavy and prolonged use is most likely to cause seizures.

column3: When administering the Rorschach, the purpose of the inquiry phase is to:
column4: C. obtain the information needed to accurately code the examinee's responses.
column5: EPPP-P4-PAS-Other Measures of Personality-04 Answer C is correct. Administration of the Rorschach ordinarily involves two phases: the free association (response) phase and the inquiry phase. During the inquiry phase, the examiner questions the examinee about what parts of the inkblot determined the examinee's responses to obtain the information needed to code his/her responses.
column8: Administration of the Rorschach ordinarily involves two phases: the free association (response) phase and the inquiry phase. During the inquiry phase, the examiner questions the examinee about what parts of the inkblot determined the examinee's responses to obtain the information needed to code his/her responses.
column10: The purpose of the inquiry phase in administering the Rorschach is to obtain the information needed to accurately code the examinee's responses.

column3: A member of an ethnic minority group rejects the values, beliefs, and cultural practices of both her own minority group and the dominant (majority) group. According to Berry (2003), this person has adopted which of the following acculturation strategies?
column5: EPPP-P4-CLI-Cross-Cultural Issues - Terms and Concepts-24 Answer A is correct. J. W. Berry's acculturation model distinguishes between four acculturation strategies based on whether a member of a minority group accepts or rejects his/her own culture and the culture of the dominant (majority) group: integration, assimilation, separation, and marginalization. A person has adopted a marginalization strategy when the person rejects his/her own minority culture and the culture of the dominant group [Conceptual approaches to acculturation, in K. M. Chun, P. Organista, and G. Main (Eds.), Acculturation: Advances in theory, measurement, and applied research (pp. 17-37), Washington, DC, American Psychological Association, 2003].
column8: J. W. Berry's acculturation model distinguishes between four acculturation strategies based on whether a member of a minority group accepts or rejects his/her own culture and the culture of the dominant (majority) group: integration, assimilation, separation, and marginalization. A person has adopted a marginalization strategy when the person rejects his/her own minority culture and the culture of the dominant group [Conceptual approaches to acculturation, in K. M. Chun, P. Organista, and G. Main (Eds.), Acculturation: Advances in theory, measurement, and applied research (pp. 17-37), Washington, DC, American Psychological Association, 2003].
column10: A person who rejects the values, beliefs, and cultural practices of both their own minority group and the dominant (majority) group has adopted the marginalization acculturation strategy.

column3: Practitioners of acceptance and commitment therapy (ACT) would most likely agree that:
column4: B. the presence of psychological pain is universal and normal.
column5: EPPP-P4-CLI-Cognitive-Behavioral Therapies-17 Answer B is correct. ACT is based on the assumptions "that psychological pain is both universal and normal and is part of what makes us human  [and] that psychological problems are maintained by excessive avoidance of painful experiences (thoughts, feelings, memories, etc.)" [J. Boorman, E. Morris, and J. Oliver, Acceptance and commitment therapy, in C. Feltham, T. Hanley, and L. A. Winter (Eds.), The SAGE handbook of counseling and psychotherapy (pp. 218-223), London, SAGE Publications Ltd., 2017].
column8: ACT is based on the assumptions "that psychological pain is both universal and normal and is part of what makes us human  [and] that psychological problems are maintained by excessive avoidance of painful experiences (thoughts, feelings, memories, etc.)" [J. Boorman, E. Morris, and J. Oliver, Acceptance and commitment therapy, in C. Feltham, T. Hanley, and L. A. Winter (Eds.), The SAGE handbook of counseling and psychotherapy (pp. 218-223), London, SAGE Publications Ltd., 2017].
column10: Practitioners of acceptance and commitment therapy (ACT) agree that the presence of psychological pain is universal and normal.

column3: According to Piaget, children begin to be able to observe another child perform a complex action and then imitate that action for the first time on the following day when they're between ________ months of age.
column5: EPPP-P4-LIF-Cognitive Development-10 Answer C is correct. The ability to imitate a complex action after a period of time when the model is no longer present is referred to as deferred imitation. According to Piaget, deferred imitation doesn't occur until the infant can form enduring mental representations, which happens during the final substage (substage six) of the sensorimotor stage when children are between 18 and 24 months of age.
column8: The ability to imitate a complex action after a period of time when the model is no longer present is referred to as deferred imitation. According to Piaget, deferred imitation doesn't occur until the infant can form enduring mental representations, which happens during the final substage (substage six) of the sensorimotor stage when children are between 18 and 24 months of age.
column10: According to Piaget, children begin to be able to observe another child perform a complex action and then imitate that action for the first time on the following day when they're between 18 and 24 months of age.

column3: An employer who's concerned about the low motivation of her employees decides to interview them to obtain information that will help her determine how to alleviate this problem. Being familiar with equity theory, she will focus on which of the following when interviewing the employees?
column4: A. their perceptions of the relative fairness of their treatment at work
column5: EPPP-P4-ORG-Theories of Motivation-22 Answer A is correct. Equity theory (Adams, 1965) predicts that worker motivation is related to a worker's perception of the relative fairness of how he or she is treated, which is based on comparisons the worker makes between his or her input/outcome ratio and the input/outcome ratios of workers doing the same or a similar job. When workers believe they're not being treated fairly (i.e., when they perceive the ratios to be unequal), this affects their motivation and performance.
column8: Equity theory (Adams, 1965) predicts that worker motivation is related to a worker's perception of the relative fairness of how he or she is treated, which is based on comparisons the worker makes between his or her input/outcome ratio and the input/outcome ratios of workers doing the same or a similar job. When workers believe they're not being treated fairly (i.e., when they perceive the ratios to be unequal), this affects their motivation and performance.
column10: When interviewing employees to determine how to alleviate low motivation, an employer familiar with equity theory will focus on the employees' perceptions of the relative fairness of their treatment at work.

column3: A researcher would use the split-plot ANOVA to analyze the data she collected in her research study when:
column4: C. her study included one between-subjects independent variable and one within-subjects independent variable.
column5: EPPP-P4-RMS-Inferential Statistical Tests-12 Answer C is correct. Knowing that the split-plot ANOVA is also known as the mixed ANOVA may have helped you identify the correct answer to this question: It is used when data are collected from a study that used a mixed design - i.e., that had at least one between-subjects variable and one within-subjects variable.
column8: Knowing that the split-plot ANOVA is also known as the mixed ANOVA may have helped you identify the correct answer to this question: It is used when data are collected from a study that used a mixed design - i.e., that had at least one between-subjects variable and one within-subjects variable.
column10: The split-plot ANOVA is used to analyze data collected from a research study that included one between-subjects independent variable and one within-subjects independent variable.

column3: An adult with traumatic brain injury is most likely to obtain the highest score on the _______ Index of the WAIS-IV.
column5: EPPP-P4-PAS-Stanford-Binet and Wechsler Tests-06 Answer A is correct. The WAIS-IV Technical Manual reports the following mean Index scores for examinees with traumatic brain injury: Verbal Comprehension = 92.1, Perceptual Reasoning = 86.1, Working Memory = 85.3, and Processing Speed = 80.5.
column8: The WAIS-IV Technical Manual reports the following mean Index scores for examinees with traumatic brain injury: Verbal Comprehension = 92.1, Perceptual Reasoning = 86.1, Working Memory = 85.3, and Processing Speed = 80.5.
column10: Adults with traumatic brain injury are most likely to obtain the highest score on the Verbal Comprehension Index of the WAIS-IV.

column3: Dr. Sholen finds that she and her intern do not have time to administer tests to all of the clients who are being referred to Dr. Sholen for psychological assessment. As a result, she decides to hire a graduate student who is working on her master's degree in clinical psychology to administer the MMPI-2 and several similar tests. With regard to ethical requirements, this:
column4: D. may be acceptable as long as the student has had adequate training and will be supervised by Dr. Sholen.
column5: EPPP-P4-ETH-APA Ethics Code Standards 9 & 10-24 Answer D is correct. This situation is addressed in Standard 9.07 of the APA's Ethics Code and Standards II.7 and II.56 of the Canadian Code of Ethics. Standard 9.07 states that "psychologists do not promote the use of psychological assessment techniques by unqualified persons, except when such use is conducted for training purposes with appropriate supervision."
column8: This situation is addressed in Standard 9.07 of the APA's Ethics Code and Standards II.7 and II.56 of the Canadian Code of Ethics. Standard 9.07 states that "psychologists do not promote the use of psychological assessment techniques by unqualified persons, except when such use is conducted for training purposes with appropriate supervision."
column10: Hiring a graduate student to administer the MMPI-2 and similar tests may be acceptable as long as the student has had adequate training and will be supervised by the psychologist.
